div.p: FRIENDSHIP IN FASHION. A COMEDY, As it is Acted at his Royal Highness the Dukes Theatre.
Written by THOMAS OTWAY.
Licenced May 31. 1678. Roger L'Estrange.
LONDON, Printed by E. F. for Richard Tonson, at his Shop within Grays-Inn-Gate, next Grays-Inn-Lane, 1678.

div.head: To the Right Honourable CHARLES Earl of DORSET and MIDDLESEX, Gentleman of his MAJESTIES Bed-Chamber, &c.
div.p:
YOur Lordship has so often and so highly obliged me, that I cannot but condemn my self for giving you a trouble so Impertinent, as this is: Considering how remiss I have been in my respects to your Lordship, in that I have not waited on you so frequently as the duty I owe your Lordship and my own Inclinations required; But the Circumstances of my Condition, whose daily business must be daily Bread, have not, nor will allow me that happiness: Be pleased then my Lord to accept this humble dedication as an Instance of his Gratitude, who in a high measure owes his well-being to you. I cannot doubt but your Lordship will protect it, for nothing ever flew to you for succor unsuccessfully, I am sure I have reason to acknowledge it. As for the unluckey censures some have past upon me for this
Play, I hope your Lordship will believe I hardly deserve 'em. For to my best remembrance, when first I was accused of the thing by some people of the World, who had perhaps as little reason to think I could be guilty of it, as to believe themselves deserved it, I made it my business to clear my self to your Lordship, whose good opinion is dearer to me then any thing which my worst Enemies can wrong me of else; I hope I convinc't your Lordship of my Innocence in the matter, which I would not have endeavoured, had it not been Just. For I thank my Stars I know my self better then (for all the Threats some have been pleased to bestow upon me) to tell a lie to save my Throat. Forgive me my Lord this trouble, continue me in your Lordships favour and good opinion, and accept of the Prayers and well-wishes of

closer.signed: Your most Humble, and most Obliged Servant, Thomas Otway.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE, Spoken by Mr. Smith.
div.l: HOW hard a task hath that poor Drudg of Stage,
That strives to please in this Fantastick Age?
It is a thing so difficult to hit,
That he's a Fool that thinks to do't by Wit;
Therefore our Author bad me plainly say,
You must not look for any in his Play.
I'th' next place, Ladies, there's no Bawdy in't,
No not so much as one well-meaning hint;
Nay more, 'twas written every word he says
On strictest Vigils and on Fasting Days,
When he his Flesh to Pennance did enjoin,
Nay took such care to work it chast and fine,
He Dissiplin'd himself at every Line.
Then Gentlemen no Libel he intends,
Tho some have strove to wrong him with his Friends;
And Poets have so very few of those,
They'd need take care whose favour 'tis they lose:
Who'd be a Poet? Parents all beware,
Cherish and Educate your Sons with care;
Breed 'em to wholsome Law, or give 'em Trades,
Let 'em not follow th' Muses, they are Jades:
How many very hopeful rising Citts
Have we of late known spoil'd by turning Wits?
Poets by Critiques are worse treated here,
Then on the Bank-side Butchers do a Bear.
Faith Sirs be kind, since now his time is come,
When he must stand or fall as you shall doom:
Give him Bear-Garden Law, that's fair play for't,
And he's content for one, to make you sport.

div.head: Act I. Scene, The Mall.
div.stage: Truman reading a Billet, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: IN a Vizor say you?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and as soon as she had deliver'd it, without any thing more, gave the word to the Coachman, drew up the Tin Lettice and away she hurry'd.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: The meaning of a Billet of this nature without a Name is a Riddle to me.— Reads.

body.p: You know me and see me often, I wish I may never see you more, except you knew better where to place your Love, or I were abler to govern mine: As you are a Gentleman, burn this so soon as it comes to your hands.—

div.p: Well, this can be no other then some Stanch Vertue of 35. that is just now fallen under the Temptation, or what is as bad, one of those Cautious Dealers that never venture but in Masquerade, where they are sure to be wondrous kind, tho' they discover no more to the Lover then he has just occasion to make use of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Truman, Good morrow, just out of your Lodging? but that I know thee better, I should swear thou hadst resolv'd to spend this day in Humiliation and Repentance for the sins of the last.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I beg your pardon! Some Lady has taken up your time. Thou canst no more rise in a Morning without a Wench, then thou canst go to Bed at Night without a Bottle. Truman, wilt thou never leave whoring?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Peace, Matrimony, peace—speak more reverently of your dearly beloved whoring. Valentine, he is the meer Spirit of Hypocrisie— h'ad hardly been married Ten Days, but he left his Wife to go home from the Play alone in her Coach, whilst he debaucht me with two Vizors in a Hackney to Supper.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Truly Goodvile, that was very civil, and may come to something— But Gentlemen it begins to grow late. Where shall we Dine?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Where you will, I am indifferent.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I had appointed to meet at Chatolins, but—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, your Cousin Malagene Goodvil.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Valentine, Thou art too much with that fellow.
'Tis true indeed he is some relation to me, but 'tis such a lying Varlet, there is no induring of him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But Rogues and Fools are so very plenty 'tis hard always to escape 'em.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Besides he dares be no more a Friend then a Foe, he never spoke well of any man behind his back, nor ill before his face: he is a general Disperser of nauseous Scandall tho' it be of his own Mother or Sister, prithee let's avoid him if we can to day.

sp.speaker: Goovd.
sp.p: 'Twill be almost impossible, for he is as impudent as he is troublesom; as there is no Company so ill but hee'l keep, so there is none so good but hee'l pretend to. If he has ever seen you once, hee'l be sure of you: And if he knows where you are, he's no more to be kept out of your Room, then you can keep him out of your Debt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He came where I was last Night roaring drunk: swore Dam him, he had bin with my Lord such a one, and had swallow'd three quarts of Champaigne for his share, said he had much ado to get away, but came then particularly to drink a Bottle with me: I was forc't to promise him I would meet him to day, to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Faith Gentlemen, let us all go dine at my house: I have snubb'd him of late, and he'l hardly venture that way so soon again: At Night I'le promise you good Company, my Wife (for I allow her for my own sake what freedom she pleases) has sent for the Fiddles to come.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Goodvile, If there be any such thing as ease in Matrimony, thou hast it: But methinks, there's as it were a Mark upon married men that makes 'em as distinguishable from one of us as your Jews are from the rest of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh there are pleasures you dream not of: he is onely confin'd by it that will be so: A man may make his Condition as easie as he pleases.—Mine is such a fond wanton Ape, I never come home, but she entertains me with fresh kindness: and Jack when I have been hunting for Game with you, and miss'd of an Opportunity, stops a Gap well enough.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: There's no Condition so wretched but has its reserve: Your Spaniel turn'd out of doors goes contentedly to his Kennel. Your Begger when he can get no better lodging, knows his old warm Bush; and your married Whore-master that misses of his Wench, goes honestly home, and there's Madam Wife.—But Goodvile, who are to be the Company at Night?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: In the first place, my Cousin Victoria your Idol, Jack Truman; then Mr. Valentine, there will be the charming Camilla, and another that never fails upon such an occasion, the unimitable Lady Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: That indeed is a worthy person, a great Critick forsooth; one that censures Plays, and takes it very ill she has none dedicated to her yet, a constant frequenter of all Masquerades and publick Meetings, a perfect Coquet, very affected, and something old.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Discourses readily of all the Love Intrigues of the Court and Town, a strange Admirer of Accomplishments and good breeding as she calls it; a restless Dancer: one that by her good will would never be out of motion.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: How Valentine! you were once a great Admirer there, have a care, how you speak too harshly of your Mistress, though the business be over. You stand well with the Ladies yet, and are held a man of principles.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: That indeed is a fine Creature. Your old harrass'd Stager has always some such resty Whore-master or another, whom she makes the best of her despair withall, and after being forsaken by half the Town besides, comforts her self in her man of principles. But now I think on't, we delay too long. I'le go before and prepare: Gentlemen you'l be sure to follow?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir, wee'l not fail to wait on you. Exit Goodvile.
Boy! is the Coach ready? Valentine! I have had the oddest adventure this Morning—ha—Malagene!
How came he hither?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Jack Truman, Monsieur Valentine, bon jour —was not that Goodvile I met coming in—hah?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, he parted hence but now.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith I'le tell ye what Gentlemen, Goodvile's a very honest Fellow as can be, but he and I are fallen out of late, though faith 'twas none of my seeking.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: No, I'le be sworn for thee, thou lov'st thy self better.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray, what was the matter Malagene?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why I was advising him to look after things better at home. The Fellow has married a young Wife, and there he lets her make Balls and give Entertainments. I was very free with him and told him of it to the purpose: for saith I should be sorry to see any ill come on't, very sorry.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But hark ye Malagene, Goodvile's a sort of a surly Companion, and apt to have so good an Opinion of himself, that he is able to manage Affairs without your advice: He might have been very severe with you upon this occasion.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p:
Severe with me! I thank you for that with all my heart, That had been the way to have made a fine piece of work on't indeed!
Hark ye, (under the Rose) he's sweetly sitted with my Cousin though.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, speak with more respect: We are his friends, and not prepar'd to rellish any of your Satyr at present.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: O Lord Sir! I beg your pardon, you are a new acquaintance there, I remember, and may design an Interest. Faith Ned, if thou dost, I'le ne'r be thy hindrance, for all she's my Kinswoman.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: The Rascal if he had an opportunity would pimp for his Sister, though but for the bare pleasure of telling it himself.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Now when he comes home, will she be hanging about his neck, with, O Lord, Dear! where have you been this Morning? I can't abide you should go abroad so soon, that I can't: You are never well but when you are with that wicked lewd Truman, and his debaucht Companion young Valentine: But that I know you are a good Dear, I should be apt to be jealous of you, that I should, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir, you are very bold with our Characters, methinks.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: I, shaw! your Servant: Sure we that know one another may be free: You may say as much of me if you please. But no matter for that, did you hear nothing of my Business last Night?—hah?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Not a word I assure you, Sir. Pray how was it? Prithee let him alone a little, Valentine.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Why, coming out of Chatolins last Night, (where it had cost me a Guinney-Club, with a Right Honourable or two of this Kingdom, which shall be nameless) just as I was getting into a Coach, who should come by but a Blustering Fellow with a woman in his hand, and swore, Dam him, the Coach was for him: we had some words, and he drew; with that I put by his pass, clos'd with him, and threw up his Heels, took away Toledo, gave him 2 or 3 good Cuts over the Face, seiz'd upon Damozel, carried her away with me to my Chamber, manag'd her all Night, and just now sent her off.—Faith, amongst friends she was a person of quality, I'le tell you that.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: What! a person of quality at that time o'th' Night, and on foot too?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ay, and one that you both know very well, but take no notice on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you may be sure we shall be very cautious of spreading any Secrets of yours of this nature.—Lying Rakehel, the highest he ever arriv'd at was a Bawd, and she too banisht him at last, because he boasted of her Favours.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Nay, not that I care very much neither, you may tell it if you will; for I think it was no more then any one wou'd have done upon the same occasion— ha.—

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Doubtless, Sir, you were much in the right: but, Valentine, we shall stay too long: 'tis time we were going.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: What, to Dinner? I'le make a third man—where shall it be?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry, we must beg your excuse this time, for we are both engag'd.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Whoo! prithee, that's all one, I am sure I know the Company; I'le go along at a venture.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, but Malagene! to make short of the Business, we are going into Company that are not very good Friends of yours, and will be very uneasie if you be there.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: What's that to the purpose?—I care as little for them as they do for me, tho' on my word, Sparks! of honest Fellows, you keep the oddest Company sometimes that ever I knew!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But, Sir, we are resolv'd to reform it, and in order thereunto desire you would leave us to our selves to day.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No—but I'le tell you, go along with me, I have discover'd a Treasure of pale Wine—I'le assure you 'tis the same the King drinks of— What say you, Jack? I am but for one Bottle or two, for faith I have resolv'd to live sober for a week.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Prithee, Tormentor, leave us! do not I know the Wine thou drink'st is as base as the Company thou keep'st? To be plain with you, we will not go with you, nor must you go with us.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Why, if one should ask the question now, whither are you going? hah?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How comes it, Malagene, you are not with your two Friends, Caper and Saunter?—you may be sure of them; they'l eat and drink, and go all over the VVorld with you.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: How canst thou think that I would keep such loathsom Company? a brace of silly talking, dancing, singing Rascals: 'Tis true, I contracted an acquaintance with 'em, I know not how; and now and then when I am out of humour, love to laugh at and abuse 'em for an hour or two—but come what will on't, I am resolv'd to go along with you to Day.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, you cannot—Why should you make so many difficulties with your friends?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Whoo! prithee leave fooling.—You would shake me off now, would you? But I know better things.—The Sham won't pass upon me, Sir, it won't, look you.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Death, we must use him ill, or there is no getting rid of him, not pass, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: No, Sir!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, leave us.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I shan't do't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But you must, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: May be not Sir.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: I am going this way. Walking off.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: So am I.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But, Sir, I must stay here a little longer.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: With all my heart! tis the same thing, I am not in hast.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Have a care, Malagene, how you provoke Truman—you'l run the hazard of a scurvy beating, my friend, if you do.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Beating! I am sorry, Sir, you know no better: pox, I am us'd to serve him so, man; let me alone, you shall see how I'le teaze him. Hark you Jack.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir, you are an impudent troublesom Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No matter for that, I shan't leave you.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir, I shall pull you by the Nose then.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Tis all one to me, do your worst.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Take that then, Sir. —Now d'ye hear— Tweaks him by the Nose.
Go about your business.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Nay, Faith, Jack, now you drive the Jest too far: what a Pox I know you are not in earnest, prithee let's go.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Death, Sir, you lye, not in earnest!—let this convince you—
How like you the Jest now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Hark you Truman, We shan't Dine together then, shall we?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith, to tell you the truth of the matter; Truman had a quarrel last Night, and we are just now going to make an end on't: 'tis that makes him so surly. Nevertheless, now I think on't better, if you'l go, you shall, perhaps we may have occasion for a third man.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No, no, if that be the business I'le say no more, puh — I hate to press into any mans Company against his Inclination. Truman! Upon my Reputation, you are very uncivil now, that you are. But hark you, I ran to the Groom-Porters last Night and lost my Money—Prithee lend me two Guinneys till next time I see thee, Child.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir, I was sure 'twould come to this at last: 'Tis here, you may command what you please from your Servant. Malagene, Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Dear Jack Truman, your humble— Exit Truman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Won't you go along with us then Malagene?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No, here are two silly Fellows coming, I'le go and divert my self a little with them at present.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, those are the very people you rail'd at so but now: you will not leave us for them? at a time when you may be so serviceable?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Hang't, you'l have no occasion for me man: Say no more on't, but take my advice, be sure you stand fast, Don't give ground, d'ye hear, push briskly, and I'le warrant you do your business.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you for your counsel, and am sorry we can't have your company but; you are ingag'd?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Are you sure though it will come to fighting? I have no mind to leave your company methinks.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, nothing so certain as that we shall fight: I wish you would go, for I fancy there will be three in the Field.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: A pox on't, now I remember, I promis'd to meet these people here, and can't avoid 'em now, I'de go with you else with all my heart Faith and Troth, but if you'd have me send a Guard, I'le do't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, Sir,—there's no danger—Nothing but the Rogues cowardize could have rid us of him. Exit Valentine.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: How now Bullies, whither so fast this Morning? I parted just now with Jack Truman and Ned Valentine: They would fain have had me to Dinner with 'em, but I was not in a humour of drinking, and to speak the truth on't, you are better Company ten to one. They ingross still all the discourse to themselves: and a man can never be free with them neither.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Malagene! we met the Delicat'st Creature but now as we came round, I am a Rascal, if I don't think her one of the finest Women in the world: I shan't get her out of my mind this Month.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: 'Twas Victoria, my Lady Fairfields Daughter that came to Town last Summer when Goodvile was marri'd. He in love with her, poor Soul! —I shall beg his pardon there as I take it— Sings.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: That's Truman's blowing: she's always lingring after him here and at the Play-house: She heats herself here every Morning against the general Course at Night, where she comes as constantly as my Lady Squeamish her self.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: I vow that's a fine person too, don't you think she has abundance of wit, Malagene? She and I did so rally Caper t'other day.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ay, it may be so.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: But did you never hear her sing? She made me sit with her till Two a Clock t'other Morning to teach her an Italian Song.
I have, and I vow she sings it wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Dam her, she's the most affected amorous Jilt, and loves young Fellows more then an old Kite does young Chicken: There is not a Coxcomb of eighteen in Town can escape her, we shall have her draw one of you into Matrimony within this Fortnight.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Malagene, Thou art the most Satyrical Thief breathing: I'd give any thing thou didst but love dancing, that I might have thee on my side sometimes.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p:
Well Malagene, I hope to see thee so in love one day, as to leave off drinking as I have done and set up for a Shape and a Face: Or what is all one, write amorous Sonnets, and fight Duels with all that do but look like Rivals. I would n •
• e in love for all the world, I vow and swear.

div.stage: Walks up and down with an affected motion.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nor I.

q.l: —An Phyllis, if you wou'd not love

sp.p: But d'ye hear, Malagene, They say Goodvile gives a Ball to Night, is it true?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Yes, I intend to be there, if I do not go to Court.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I am glad of it with all my heart —Saunter — There's my Lady, to be sure, she'l not fail.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: But will you go, Malagene? Goodvile and you are at a distance.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Whoo! pox that's nothing, I'le go for all that. But faith, I shou'd meet my Lord—at Court to Night: besides, I han't been in the Drawing Room these three days; the Company will wonder what's become of me.
She here! Nay then—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladiships most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Mr. Caper! your most Devoted.—Oh dear Mr. Saunter! a thousand thanks to you for my Song.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Your Ladiship does your Servant too much honour.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Mr. Caper, you are a stranger indeed, I have not seen you this two days: Lord, where d'ye live?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I should have waited on your Ladiship, but was so tired at the Masquerade at my Lord Flutters t'other Night. Dances and capers.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, Mr. Goodvile gives a Ball to Night: Will your Ladiship be there?

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Yes; I heard of it this Morning, Victoria sent me word.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, d'ye hear the News? Goodvile makes a Ball to Night: I hope I shall have the honour of your Ladiships company.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Oh, by all means: Mr. Caper, pray don't you fail us.
Oh Lord, Mr. Malagene, I beg your pardon, upon my honour I did not see you, I was so engaged in the Civilities of these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Your Wit and Beauty, Madam, must command the Honour and Admiration of all the World. But when did your Ladiship see Mr. Valentine?

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Oh, name him not, Mr. Malagene, he's the unworthi'st basest Fellow— besides he has no principles nor breeding: I wonder you Gentlemen will keep him company. I'le swear he's enough to bring an Odium on the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p:
The truth on't is, Madam, I do d ••
〈◊〉 with him now and then, because the Fellow has some wit, but it is •• en better Company is out of the way; and faith he's always very civil to me as can be: I can rule him.

sp.speaker: L. Squem.
sp.p: Oh Lord, 'tis impossible. Wit! Why he was abroad but two years, and all that time too in an Academy, he knows not • ing of the Intrigues of the French Court, and has the worst mien in the world: he has a sort of an ill-natur'd way of talking indeed, and they say makes bold with me sometimes, but I'le assure you I scorn him.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Truly he has made very bold with you, or he is foully bely'd: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: They say, he's grown a great Admirer of Madam Camilla of late, who passes for a Wit forsooth. 'Tis true, she's well enough, but I suppose is not the first that has been troubled with his impertinent Addresses.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Indeed he would not let me alone, till I brought him acquainted there: he owes that happiness to me. But methinks your Ladiship speaks with something of heat—By Heav'n she's jealous!

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: No, I assure you, Sir, I am not concern'd at it in the least.
But did you ever hear 'em discourse any thing of me?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Never any ill, Madam, onely a little idle Raillery now and then; but Truman and he are wont to be something lavish when they have been drunk in my company. — 'Twill work.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Nay, I know he has spoken dishonourably of me behind my back, because he fail'd in his filthy designs. Madam Camilla may deserve better of him, I doubt not: but if I am not reveng'd on his falshood— [Aside] Mr. Caper.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Where do you go to day?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Will your Ladiship be at the new Play?

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: No, I saw it the first day, and don't like it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Madam, it has no ill Character about the Town.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, the Town is no Judge. 'Tis a Tragedy, and I'le assure you there's nothing in it that's moving.
I love a Tragedy that moves mightily.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Does your Ladiship know who writ it?

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Yes, the Poet came and read it to me at my Lodgings: He is but a young man, and I suppose he has not been a Writer long: besides, he has had little or no conversation with the Court, which has been the reason he has committed a great many Indecorums in the conduct of it.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: I did not like it neither for my part; There was never a Song in it, ha?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, nor so much as a Dance.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Oh, it's impossible it should take if there were neither Song nor Dance in it.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: And then their Comedies now a days are the filthiest things, full of Bawdy and nauseous doings which they mistake for raillery and intrigue; besides they have no wit in 'em neither, for all their Gentlemen and men of wit, as they style 'em, are either silly conceited impudent Coxcombs, or else rude ill-mannerly drunken Fellows— fogh —I am asham'd any one should pretend to write a Comedy, that does not know the nicer rules of the Court, and all the Intrigues and Gallantries that pass, I vow.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Who would improve in those things, must consult with your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: I swear, Mr. Malagene, you are an obliging person: I wonder the world should be so malicious to give you so undeserving a Character as they do: I always found you extremely generous and a person of worth.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: In troth, Madam, your Ladiship and my self are the subjects of abundance of envy: for I love to be malicious now and then, and faith, am the very scourge of the Court, they all stand in awe of me, for I must speak what I know, tho' sometimes I am used a little scurvily for it; but faith I can't help it, 'tis my way.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, really I love scandal extremely too sometimes, so it be decently manag'd — But as I was saying, there is not a person in the world understands the Intrigues of the Court better than my self: I am the general Confident of the Drawing Room, and know the loves of all the people of quality in Town.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Dear Madam, how stands the Affair between my Lord Supple and Madam Lofty?

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Worse then ever: 'Tis very provoking to see how she uses the poor Creature: but the truth is, she can never be at rest for him; he's more troublesom then an old Husband, continually whispering his softnesses and making his vowes, till at last she is forc'd to fly to me for shelter, and then we do so laugh—which the good natur'd Creature takes so patiently—I swear, I pity him.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: But my Lady Colt they say is kinder to the Sparkish Mr. Pruneit.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Mr. Saunter, that you should understand no better; to my knowledge it is all false: I know all that Intrigue from the beginning to the ending, it has been off this Month—besides he keeps a Player again—Oh, Mr. Saunter! whatever you do, never concern your self with those Players.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Madam, I have left the folly long since: When first I came to Town, I must confess I had a Gallantry there: but since I have been acquainted with your Ladiships Wit and Beauty, I have learnt to lay out my heart to better advantage—I think that was finely said!

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: I'le swear, Mr. Saunter, you have the most Court-like way of expressing your self—

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Madam! Bows and cringes.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Mr. Malagene, these are both my intimate acquaintance, and I le swear, I am proud of 'em. Here is Mr. Saunter sings the French manner better then ever I heard any English Gentleman in my life: besides he pronounces his English in singing with a French kind of a Tone or Accent, that gives it a strange beauty—Sweet Sir, do me the favour of the last new Song.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Let me die! your Ladiship obliges me beyond expression—Malagene, thou shalt hear me.

div.stage: Sings a Song in a French Tone.

sp.speaker: Mala.
sp.p: What a Devil was this, I understand not a word on't.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Ha, Malagene, ha?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Did you ever hear any thing so fine?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Never, Madam, never: I swear, your Ladiship is a great Judge.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: but how plain and distinctly too every word was pronounc'd?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Oh, to admiration, to admiration.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Saunter, you are a charming Creature—Oh sad, Mr. Caper, I long till Night comes: I'le dance with no body but you to Night, for I swear I believe I shall be out of humour.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: That's more then she ever was in her life, so long as she had a Fool or a Fiddle in her company.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Tho' really I love Dancing immoderately.—But now you talk of Intrigues, I am mistaken if you don't see something where we are going to Night.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: What, Goodvile is to commence Cuckold, is it not so?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh, fie, Mr. Malagene, fie: I vow you'l make me hate you, if you talk so strangely:—but let me die, I can't but laugh—ha, ha, ha.— Well, Gentlemen, you shall Dine with me to day—What say you Mr. Malagene, will you go?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Your Ladiship may be sure of me, I hate to break good Company.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: And pray now let us be very severe and talk maliciously of all the Town. Mr. Caper your hand: Oh, dear Mr. Saunter, how shall I divide my self—I'le swear, I am strangely at a loss—Mr. Malagene, you must be Mr. Saunters Mistriss I think at present.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam,—Sweet Mr. Saunter, your hand: I swear, you are a charming Creature, and your Courtship is as extraordinary as your Voice.—Let me die, and I vow I must have t'other Song after Dinner, for I am very humoursom and very whimsical I think: ha, ha, ha.

div.head: THE SECOND ACT. SCENE, The Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: DId you deliver the Billet?

sp.speaker: Lettic.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, faithfully.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: But are you sure you did?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Can your Ladiship think I would be guilty of the least neglect in a Concern of such moment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: And are you sure he Dines here to day?

sp.speaker: Lettic.
sp.p: Madam, they are now at Dinner below: Mr. Valentine's there too. Oh, I'le swear he's a fine man, the most courteous person!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: What, because he hunts and kisses you when he's drunk? No, Lettice, Truman, Truman, Oh that Truman!

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: I wonder your Ladiship should be so taken with him: were I to choose, I should think my Master the more agreeable man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: And you may take him if you will; he is as much a Husband as one would wish: I have not seen him this Fortnight; he never comes home till Four in the Morning, and then he sneaks to his separate Bed, where he lies till Afternoon, then rises and out again upon his Parole: flesh and bloud can't endure it.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: But he always visits your Ladiship first.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: That's his Policy, as great Debtors are always very respectfull and acknowledging where they never mean to pay. 'Tis true, he gives me what freedom I can desire, but God knows that's all.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: And where's the pleasure of going abroad and getting a stomach, to return and starve at home?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I laugh though to think what an easie fool he believes me; he thinks me the most contented, innocent, harmless Turtle breathing, the very pattern of patience.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: A Jewel of a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: And as blind with love as his own good opinion of himself has made him.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: And can you find in your heart to wrong so good a natur'd compleat well-meaning harmless Husband, that has so good an opinion of you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Ha, wrong him! what you say, Lettice? I wrong my Husband! such another word forfeits my good opinion of thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: What meant the Billet to Mr. Truman then this Morning?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p:
To make him my friend perhaps, and discover if I can who
it is that wrongs me in my Husbands affection: for I am sure I have a Rival. And I am apt to believe Victoria deserves no better then ordinary of me, if the truth were known.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Why, she is his near Kinswoman and lives here in the house with you, besides he would never dishonour his own Family surely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: You are a Fool, Lettice, the nearness of bloud is the least thing considered. Besides, as I have heard, 'tis almost the onely way Relations care to be kind to one another now a days.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Yet, Madam, you never meet, but you are as kind and fond of him, as if you had all the joyes of love about you. Lord! How can you dissemble with him so? Besides, Mr. Truman, Madam, you know is his Friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. Goodv.
sp.p: Oh, if I would ever consent to wrong my Husband (which Heav'n forbid, Lettice!) it should be, to choose, with his Friend. For such a one has a double Obligation to secrecy, as well for his own Honour as mine. But I'le swear, Lettice, you are an idle Girl for talking so much of this, that you are: 'Tis enough to put ill thoughts into ones head, which I am the most averse to of all things in the world.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: But, Madam, Thoughts are free, and it is as hard not to think a little idly sometimes, as it is to be always in good humour. But it would make any one laugh, to think Mr. Truman should be in love with Madam Victoria, if all be reall which your Ladiship suspects.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Ay, and with a design of Marriage too: but a ranging Gallant thinks he fathoms all, and counts it as much beneath his experience to doubt his security in a Wife, as success in a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Besides, after a little time, he is so very industrious in Cuckolding others, that he never dreams how swimmingly his own Affairs are manag'd at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: But hush—she's here.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: A happy Day to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Dear Cousin, your humble Servant: have you heard who are below?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Yes, young Truman and his inseparable Companion Valentine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Well, what will you do Cousin, Truman comes resolv'd on Conquest; for with the Advantages he has in your Heart already, 'tis impossible you should be able to hold out against him.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Yes, powerfull Champaign as they call it may do much, a spark can no more refrain running into love after a Bottle, then a drunken Country Vicar can avoid disputing of Religion when his Patron's Ale grows stronger then his Reason.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Come, come, dissemble your Inclinations as artfully as you please, I am sure they are not so indifferent, but they may be easily discerned.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, you may be mistaken in your guess.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: How! I doubt it is some other man then has caused this alteration in you.—Lord, Lettice, is she not extremely alter'd?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Alter'd, Madam, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Nay, Lettice, fetch a Glass and let her see her self; Lord, you are paler then you use to be.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Ay, and then that blewness under the eyes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Besides, you are not so lively as I have known you: pardon me Cousin.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Well, if there be a fault, Marriage will cure all.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: I'le assure you, I have none that I know off stands in need of so desperate a remedy. Marriage! fault! What can all this tend to?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Well, what now?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam, Camilla is coming to wait upon your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Ha, Camilla! Tell her I'le attend her: Won't you go with me Victoria?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: I'le but step into my Chamber, and follow you instantly.
Whither can all this drive? Surely she has discovered something of Goodvile's love and mine: if she has, I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Victoria! your Cousin is not here, is she? What, in Clouds? I stole this Minute from my friends on purpose to see thee, and must not I have a look? not a word?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Oh, I am ruin'd and lost for ever. I fear your Wife has had some knowledge of our Loves: And if it be so, what will then become of me?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Prithee, no more: my Wife! she has too good an opinion of her self, to have any ill one of me; and would as soon believe her Glass could flatter her, as I be false to her: my Wife! —ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Yes, I am sure it must be so; it can be no otherwise: But you are satisfi'd, and now have nothing more to do, but to leave me to be miserable.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Leave thee! By Heav'n I'de sooner renounce my Family, and own my self the Bastard of a Rascal: Come, quiet thy doubts, Truman is here, and take my Love for thy Security, he shall be thine to Night.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: I have great reason to expect it indeed, that you would hazard your Interest in so good a Friend for the reparation of my Honour, that so little concerns you, and which you have already made your best of.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
No more of that, Love's my Province; and thine is too
dear to me to be neglected. 'Tis true, I have made him my Friend, and I hope he will deserve it, by doing thee that justice which I am incapable of.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: You can promise easily.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Ay, and as resolutely perform: when I have heated him with Wine, prepare to receive him.
Ha, she here!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodvile.
sp.p: So, so, Mr. Goodvile, are you there indeed? I thought I should catch you.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Faith, my Dear, I have been speaking a good word for Jack Truman; my Cousin Victoria's too cruel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Oh, fie, Victoria! Can you be so hard hearted to deny any thing, when Mr. Goodvile is an Advocate?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: I must confess it is with some difficulty; but should I too easily comply upon Mr. Goodvile's intercession, who knows but your Ladiship might be jealous? For he that can prevail for another, may presume there's hopes for himself.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Ay, but Cousin, I know you are my Friend, and would not, though but in regard of that, do me such injury: Besides, Mr. Goodvile knows I dare trust him. Don't you, Love?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Trust me! yes, for if you don't, 'tis all one—Credulous Innocence! Aside.
Alas, my Dear, were I as false as thou art good, thy generous Confidence would shame me into honesty.

sp.speaker: Camill.
sp.p: For Heav'ns sake, Madam, save me! — Mr. Goodvile, 'tis safer travelling through the Desarts of Arabia, then entring your House: Had I not ran hard for it, I had been devour'd, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, are you herded? it will be to little purpose, I am stanch, and never change my Game.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But when you have lost it, is fresh start up, you can be as fully satisfied, who hunt more for the love of the sport, then for the sake of the prey.

sp.speaker: Valent.
sp.p: But, Madam, should you chance to be taken, look to't, for I shall touse and worry you most unmercifully, till I have reveng'd my self severely, for the pains you cost me catching.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Therefore I am resolv'd to keep out of your reach; Lord! what would become of such a poor little Creature as I am, in the Paws of so ravenous an Animal?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But are you too, Lady, so wild, as Mrs. Camilla?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, to the full! But I hope you are not so unmercifull as Mr. Valentine.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: No, Madam, quite on the contrary, as soft and pliant as your Pillow, you may mould me to your own ease and pleasure, which way you will.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: 'Tis strange two of such different Tempers should so well agree: Methinks you look like two as roaring, ranting, tory rory Sparks as one would wish to meet withall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, at the Play-house in a Vizor, when you come drest and prepar'd for the Encounter; there indeed we can be as unanimously Modish and Impertinent as the pertest Coxcombs of 'em all, till like them too, we lose our hearts, and never know what becomes of 'em.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: But the comfort is, you are sure to find 'em again in the next Bottle.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Then drink 'em down to the Ladies Healths, and they are as well at ease as ever they were.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Why, you would not be so unconscionable as to have us two such whining crop-sick Lovers, as sigh away their hours, and write lamentable Ditties to be sung about the Town by Fools and Bullies in Taverns.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Till some Smithfield Doggrel taking the hint, swells the Sonnet to a Ballad, and Chloris dwindles into a Kitchin-Wench.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: 'Tis presum'd then you are of that familiar Tribe that never make Love but by contraries, and rally our Faults when you pretend to admire our perfections.

sp.speaker: Camill.
sp.p: As if the onely way to raise a good opinion of your selves, were to let us know how ill a one you have of us.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, 'tis a hard world, and when Beauty is held at so dear a rate, 'tis the best way to beat down the Market as much as we can.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But you shall find, Ladies, we'l bid like Chapmen for all that.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: You had best have a care though, lest you over-reach your selves, and repent of your purchase when 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: Besides, I hate a Dutch Bargain that's made in heat of Wine, for the love it raises is generally like the courage it gives, very extraordinary, but very short liv'd.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: How, Madam! have a care what you say; Wine is the Prince of Love, and all Ladies that speak against it, forfeit their Charter. I must not have my Favourite traduc'd.
Boy, bring some Wine, you shall prove its good effects, and then acknowledge it your Friend. We'l drink—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Till your Brains are afloat, and all the rest sink.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I find then, Ladies, you have the like opinion of our Heads, as you have of our Hearts.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Really, Sir, you are much in the right.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
But if your Ladiship should be in the wrong.—Tho' Love like Wine be a good refresher, yet 'tis much more dangerous to be too busie withall.
And though now and then I may over-heat my Head with drinking; yet confound me, I think I shall have a care never to break my heart with loving.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: But Sir, if all men were of your cruel temper, what would become of those tender hearted Creatures that cannot forbear saluting ye with a Billet in a Morning, though it comes without a Name, and makes you as unsatisfi'd as they poor Creatures are themselves?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Hah, this concerns me! Blockhead, dull leaden Sot that I was, not to be sensible it must be she, and none but she, could send mine this Morning. Well, poor Jack Truman look to thy self, snares are laid for thee; —but the Vertuous must suffer Temptation: And Heav'n knows all flesh is frail.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Now Boy, fill the Glasses. But before we proceed, one thing is to be consider'd: My Dear, you and I are to be no Man and Wife for this day, but be as indifferent, and take as little notice one of another, as we may chance to do seven years hence: but at Night—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A very fair proposal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Agreed, Sir, if you will have it so.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: The Wine—now each man to his post. They separate, Goodv. to Cam. Val. to Victo. Trum. to Mrs. Goodv.
The word. All take Glasses.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Love and Wine. Enter Lettice.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Pass—
Now that nothing may be wanting, Lettice you must sing the Song I brought home t'other Morning, for Musick is as great an encouragement to drinking, as fighting.

lg.l: Lettice sings. How bless'd he appears,
That revels and loves out his happy years,
That fiercely spurs on till he finish his race:
And knowing life's short, chooses living apace.
To cares we were born, 'twere a folly to doubt it,
Then love and rejoyce, there's no living without it.
But as fate approaches, the brave still are bolder.
The joys of Love with our Youth slide away,
But yet there are pleasures that never decay:
When Beauty grows dull, and our Passions grow cold,
Wine still keeps its Charms, and we drink when w'are old.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: So, now show me an Enemy to divine harmonious Drinking!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady Squeamish is below, just alighted out of her Coach.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Nay then drinking will have the major Vote against it: She is the most exact observer of Decorums and Decency alive. But she is not alone I hope?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Sir, there is Mr. Malagene with her, and three more Gentlemen; one they call Sir Noble Clumsey, a full portly Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: That's a hopefull Animal, an elder Brother, of a fair Estate, and her Kinsman, newly come up to Town, whom her Ladiship has undertaken to polish and make a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis such a fulsom over-grown Rogue, yet hopes to be a fine Spark, and a very Courtly Youth; he has been this half year endeavouring at a shape, which he loves eating and drinking too well ever to attain to. The other I'le warrant you, are the nimble Mr. Caper, and his polite Companion Mr. Saunter.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: She's never without a Kennel of Fools at her heels, and we may know as well when she is near by the noise her Coxcombs make, as we know when a certain Spark of this Town is at hand by the new fangled gingle of his Coach. She comes—and wo be to the VVretch whom she first lights upon.

div.stage: Enter L. Squeamish, Sir Noble Clumsey, Malag. Caper and Saunter.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Dear Madam Goodvile, ten thousand happinesses wait on you: fair Madam Victoria, sweet charming Camilla, which way shall I express my Service to you.—Cousin your honour, your honour to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Ladies, as low as Knee can bend, or Head can bow, I salute you all▪ And Gallants, I am your most humble, most obliged, and most devoted Servant.—That I learn'd at the end of an Epistle Dedicatory.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Sir Noble Clumsey is too great a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I can complement upon an occasion; my Lady knows I am a pretty apt Scholar.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Gallants, you must pardon my Cousin here, he is but as it were a Novice yet, and has had little Conversation but what I have had the honour to instruct him in.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: But let me tell you, he is a man of parts, and one that I respect and honour: 'Pray Gentlemen know my Friend.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hark you Malagene, how durst you venture hither, knowing that Goodvile and Truman care so little for your company?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: O, Sir, your Servant, your Servant, Sir; I guess'd this was the Duel you were going about: I should not have left you else faith Ned, I should not.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: But, Madam, can the worthy Knight your Kinsman drink? What think you Sir Noble of the Ladies Healths?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: In a Glass of small Beer, if you please.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh sweet Mr. Goodvile, don't tempt him to drink, dont! I'le swear, I am so afraid he should spoil himself with drinking. Lord, how I should loath a Fellow with a red Nose!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: See, Truman, the two Coxcombs are already boarding our Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Oh, 'twere pity to interrupt 'em; a woman loves to play and fondle with a Coxcomb sometimes as naturally, as with a Lap-Dog; and I could no more be jealous of one then of the other.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am not of your opinion; they are too apt to love any thing that but makes 'em sport: And the familiarity of Fools proceeds often-times from a priviledge we are not aware of. For my part, I shall make bold to divert.—Mr. Saunter a word: Have you any pretences with that Lady? hah?

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Some small encouragement I have had, Sir; but I never make my boast of those Favours, never.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'twere not your best course.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Oh Lord, you are pleas'd to be merry: Sure he takes me for a Fool; but no matter for that.—Sings. —Would Phyllis be mine, and for, &c.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, the Fiddles are below, shall I call 'em up?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: No, let 'em stay a little, we'l dance below.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hah, the Fiddles! Boy, where are you? Caper capers.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Have you brought my Dancing-shoos?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Sir, you gave me no order: but your Fiddle is below under the Seat of the Coach.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Rascal, Dog, Fool; when did you ever know me go abroad without my Dancing-shoos? Sirrah, run home and fetch 'em quickly, or I'le cut off both your Ears, and have 'em fasten'd to the Heels of those I have on.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: It is an unpardonable fault, Sir, that your Boy should forget your Dancing-shoos.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ay, hang him, Blockhead, he has no sense; I must get rid of him as soon as I can: I would no more dance in a pair of shoos that we commonly wear, then I would ride a race in a pair of Gambado's.

sp.speaker: L. Squeam.
sp.p: Mr. Valentine I hope is a better bred Gentleman then to leave his Mistriss for Wine. I hear, Sir, there is a love between you and Madam Camilla? Thou Monster of perjury. To Val.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, you are much in the right; there is abundance of love on my side, but I can find very little on hers: If your Ladiship would but stand my Friend upon this occasion.—I think this is civil.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: I'le swear, Sir, you are a most obliging person—

Ladies and Gallants, poor Mr. Valentine here is fallen in love, and has
desired me to be his Advocate: Who could withstand that Eye, that Lip, that Shape and Mein; besides a thousand Graces in every thing he does? Oh lovely Camilla! guard, guard your Heart; but I'lle swear, if it were my own case, I doubt I should not—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Madam? what means all this?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Poor Ned Valentine!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: 'Tis but what I told him he must look for: but stay, there is more yet coming.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Nay, this is not half of what thou art to expect; I'le haunt thee worse then thy ill Genius, take all opportunities to expose thy folly and falshood every where, till I have made thee as ridiculous to our whole Sex, as thou art odious to me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But has your Ladiship no mercy? will nothing but my ruine appease you? Why should you choose by your malice to expose your decay of years, and lay open your poor Lovers follies to all, because you could improve 'em to your own use no longer? Approaches.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Come not near me, Traytor,—Lord, Madam Camilla, how can you be so cruel? See, see, how wildly he looks: for Heav'n sake have a care of him; I fear he is distemper'd in his mind: What pity 'tis so hopeful a Gentleman should run mad for Love,—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Good.
sp.p: Dear Madam, how can you use Mr. Valentine so? 'Tis enough to put him out of humour and spoil him for being good company all the day after it.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Madam, 'tis the greatest pleasure to me in the world: Let me die, but I love to railly a bashfull young Lover, and put him out of count'nance, at my heart.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, and I'le swear the Devil and all's in her wit, when she sets on't. Poor Ned Valentine! Lord, how sillily he looks!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ay, and would fain be angry if he knew but how.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hark you Coxcomb, I can be angry, very angry, d'ye mark me?

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: No, but Sir, don't be in a passion, my Lady will have her humour; but she's a very good woman at the bottom.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Very likely Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Now, Madam, if your Ladiship thinks fit, we'l withdraw and leave the Gentlemen to themselves a little; onely Mr. Caper and Mr. Saunter must do us the honour of their company.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Say you so, Madam? I'faith and you shall have it. Come Caper, we are the men for the Ladies, I see that.—Hey Boys!

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh dear and sweet Mr. Saunter shall oblige us with a Song.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: O Madam, Ten thousand, ten thousand if you please: I'le swear, I believe I could sing all Day and all Night, and never be weary. Sings.

q.l: When Phyllis watcht her harmless Sheep,

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: A happy riddance this: Now Gentlemen for one Bottle to entertain our noble Friend and now acquaintance, Sir Noble Clumsey.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Really Gallants, I must beg your pardon, I dare not drink, for I have but a very weak Brain, Sir, and my Head won't bear it.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Oh, surely that honourable Bulk could never be maintain'd with thin regular Diet and small Beer.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: I must confess, Sir, I am something plump, but a little fat is comely, I would not be too lean.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No, by no means my Dear, thou hast an heroick Face which well becomes the noble port and fulness of thy Body.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Goodvile, we have a Suit to you: Here is Malagene has been sometime in a Cloud, for this once receive him into good Grace and Favour again.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Faith, Goodvile do, for without any more words, I love thee with all my heart—Faith and Troth—give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: But Sir should I allow you my Countenance, you would be very drunk, very rude, and very unmannerly I fear.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Drunk, Sir? I scorn your words, I'de have you know I han't been drunk this week; no, I am the Son of a Whore if I wont be very sober: This noble Knight shall be security for my good behaviour. Wilt thou not Knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Sir, you are a person altogether a stranger to me; and I have sworn never to be bound for any man.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Oh but Sir Noble, you are oblig'd in honour to serve a Gentleman and your friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir? oblig'd in honour? I am satisfi'd. Sir, this Gentleman is my Friend and Acquaintance, and whatsoever he says I'le stand to.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Hark thee Son of Mars, thou art a Knight already, I'le marry thee to a Lady of my acquaintance, and have thee made a Lord.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Boy, the Wine, give Sir Noble his Glass, —Gentlemen, Sir Noble's Ladies Health.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Od's my life, I'le drink that tho' I die for't. Gallants, I have a Lady in this Head of mine, and that you shall find anon. By my Troth, I think this be a Glass of good Wine!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Say you so? take the other Glass then Sir Noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: 'Fore George, and so I will. Pox on't, let it be a brimmer: Gentlemen, God save the King.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Well said my lovely man of might: His worship grows good company.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir Noble, you are a great Acquaintance with Mr. Caper and Mr. Saunter, they are men of pretty parts.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Oh Sir, the finest persons—the most obliging well-bred complaisant modish Gentlemen: They are acquainted with all the Ladies in Town, and are men of fine estates.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p:
This Rogue is one of those Earthy Mongrels that knows the
value of nothing but a good Estate, and loves a fellow with a great deal of Land and a Title, though his Grandfather were a Blacksmith.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: How say you Sir, a good Estate? od's heart, give me the other Glass, I have two thousand pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Say'st thou so? Boy, bring more Wine; Wine in abundance, Sirrah d'ye hear? Frank Goodvile, thou see'st I am free, for Faith I hate Ceremony, and would fain make the Knight merry.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Malagene, it shall be your task; drink him up lustily, and when that's done, wee'l bring him to my Lady his Cousin, it may make some sport.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A very good proposal.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Say no more, thy word's a Law, and it shall be done: Come, bear up my lusty Limb of honour, and hang sobriety.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Ay, so say I, hang sobriety—drink, whore, rant, roar, swear, make a noise, and all that: But be honest, do'st hear, be honest.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: I would very fain be so if I could: But the damn'd Billet this Morning won't out of my head. Well, Madam Goodvile, if any mischief comes on't, 'tis your own fault, not mine. I did not strike first, and there's an end on't. Musick within.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Sir, the Fiddles are ready, and the Ladies desire your Company.—Mr. Truman, my Lady wants you.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Say'st thou so? I thank thee for thy news with all my heart. The Devil I see will get the better on't, and there is no resisting.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Sir Noble, my Lady Squeamish sent me to tell you, she wants your company to dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Tell her, I am busie about a grand Affair of the Nation, and cannot come.—Dance? I look like a Dancer indeed! but these women will be always putting us on more then we can do.
Boy, give me more Wine.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Malagene, remember, and use expedition.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Sirrah, do you know me? I am a Knight: And here's a Health to all the VVhores in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Not forgetting all the Ladies within. Now we are alone I may talk. [Drinks.]

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: So, there's for you, do you see? Breaks a Glass.
Sirrah, don't you look scurvily, I have money in my Pocket, you must know that.—Bring us more Wine.
Malagene, thou art a pretty Fellow; do'st thou love me? Give me thy hand: I will salute thy under Lip. Staggers.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Hah, what's the meaning of this? I doubt I shall almost be drunk as soon as the Knight. Sir Noble, canst thou whore?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: How, whore! what a question's there? Thou shalt be my Pimp, and I'le prefer thee.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: What a Rascal this Knight is? I have known as worthy a person as himself a Pimp, and one that thought it no blemish to his honour neither.

div.stage: Enter Lady Squeamish at the Door.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Hah, my Lady Cousin?—Faith, Madam, you see I am at it.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: The Devil's in't, I think, we could no sooner talk of Whores, but she must come in, with a Pox to her. Madam, your Ladishps most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh, odious! insufferable! Who would have thought, Cousin, you would have serv'd me so — fough how he stinks of Wine, I can smell him hither.—How have you the patience to hear the noise of Fiddles, and spend your time in nasty drinking?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Hum! 'tis a good Creature: lovely Lady, thou shalt take thy Glass.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Uh gud murther, I had rather you had offered me a Toad.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Then Valentine, here's a Health to my Lady Cousins Pelion upon Ossa. Drinks and breaks Glass.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Lord, dear Mr. Malagene, what's that?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: A certain place Madam in Greece, much talkt of by the Ancients; the noble Gentleman is well read.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Nay he is an ingenious person I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Now Lady bright I am wholly thy Slave: Give me thy hand, I'l go straight and begin my Grandmothers kissing Dance; but first design me the private honour of thy Lip.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Nay, fie Sir Noble! how I hate you now! for shame be not so rude: I'le swear you are quite spoiled. Get you gone, you good natur'd Toad you.

div.head: THE THIRD ACT. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Goodvile.
sp.p: WHat a damn'd Chicken-brain'd Fellow am I grown? If I but dip my Bill I am giddy. Now am I as hot-headed with my bare two Bottles, as a drunken Prentice on a Holiday. Truman marries Victoria, that's resolv'd on, and so one Care is over. But then Camilla! how I shall get possession of her.—Well, my mind misgives me I shall do something may call my Discretion in question, and yet I can't avoid it. Camilla I do love and must have her, come what will on't: And no time so fit to begin the Enterprize as this; she may make a good Wife for Valentine for all that.
Fie, Gentlemen, without the Ladies! Did you quit Champaign for this? Faith I begin to despair of you, and doubt you are grown as weak Lovers as Drinkers.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Goodvile thou hast no Conscience: A decay'd Cavalier Captain that drinks Journey-work under a Deputy Lieutenant in the Country is not able to keep thee company. Two Bottles, as I take it, is no such trifling matter.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh but I hate to be baulkt, and a friend that leaves me at two Bottles, is as unkind as a Mistriss that jilts me when I thought I had made sure of the Business. But Gallants, how stand the Affairs of love? Truman, is Victoria kind? I question not your friendship in the matter, but trust the honour of my Family in your hands.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He little thinks Truman is inform'd of all, and no longer a stranger on what score he is so wondrous civil. But I am mistaken, if he be behind with him in kindness long. Aside.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: A pox on't, I am afraid this Marriage will never agree with me, methinks the very thought on't goes a little against my stomach: Like a young Thief, though I have some itching to be at it, yet I am loth to venture what may follow.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
Well, I'le go in and better prepare Victoria; in the mean time
believe it onely my ambition to be as well ally'd in bloud as friendship to so good and generous a person as Truman.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: What a damn'd Creature man is! Valentine, did'st thou believe this fellow could be a Villain?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I must confess, it something surprizes me; he might have found out a fitter person to put his Mistriss upon, then his Friend: but how the Devil got you the knowledge of it?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Faith I'le tell thee; for I think I am no way oblig'd to conceal it—his Wife, even his very wife told me all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I begin to suspect that Mrs. Goodvile has no ill opinion of you; I observ'd something but now very obliging towards you: Besides when a Woman begins to betray her Husbands secrets, 'tis a certain sign she has a mind to communicate very important ones of her own.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Valentine no more of that; Though it would be a rare revenge to make a Cuckold of this smiling Rogue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis 50 times better then cutting his Throat, that were to do him more honour then he deserves.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the rarest sport—Jack Truman, Ned Valentine.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Why, whats the matter? where?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Yonder's my Rogue of a Knight as drunk as a Porter; and faith Jack I am but little better.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Dear Sir, and what of all this?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why with a Bottle under his arm, and a Beer-glass in his hand I set him full drive at my Lady Squeamish; for nothing else but to make mischief Ned—nothing else in the world; for every body knows I am the worst natur'd fellow breathing: 'Tis my way of wit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do you love no body then?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No not I: yes, a pox on't I love you well enough, because ye are a Rogue I have known a good while. Though should I take the least prejudice against you, I could not afford you a good word behind your back for my heart.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir, we are much obliged to you: 'Tis a sign the Rogue is drunk that he speaks truth.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: I tell you what I did t'other day: faith 'tis as good a jest as ever you heard.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray Sir do.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why walking along, a lame Fellow follow'd me, and askt my Charity, (which by the way was a pretty proposition to me:) being in one of my witty merry fits, I askt him how long he had been in that condition? The poor Fellow shook his head and told me he was born so.— But how d'ye think I serv'd him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, the Devil knows.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: I show'd my parts I think; for I tript up both his wooden Legs, and walkt off gravely about my business.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: And this you say is your way of wit?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ay altogether this and Mimickry: I am a very good Mimick; I can act Punchinello, Scaramouchio, Harlequin, Prince Prettyman, or any thing. I can act the rumbling of a Wheelbarrow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The rumbling of a Wheel-barrow!

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ay, the rumbling of a Wheel-barrow, so I say—Nay, more then that, I can act a Sow and Piggs, Sausages a broiling, a Shoulder of Mutton a roasting: I can act a Fly in a Honey-pot.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: That indeed must be the effect of very curious observation.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No, hang it, I never make it my business to observe any thing, that is Mechanick. But all this I do, you shall see me if you will: But here comes her Ladiship and Sir Noble.

div.stage: Enter Lady Squeamish and Sir Noble.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh dear Mr Truman rescue me. Nay, Sir Noble, for Heav'ns sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: I tell thee Lady, I must embrace thy lovely body. Sir, do you know me? I am Sir Noble Clumsey: I am a Rogue of an Estate, and live I—Do you want any money? I have fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay good Sir Noble, none of your generosity we beseech you. The Lady, the Lady Sir Noble.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis all one to me if you won't take it, there it is.— Hang money, my Father was an Alderman.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Tis pity good Guinneys should be spoil'd: Sir Noble, by your leave. Picks 'em up.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: But Sir you will not keep my money?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Oh, hang money Sir, your Father was an Alderman.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Well, get thee gone for an Arch-wagg—I do but sham all this while:—But by Dad he's pure company.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Was there ever such a Blockhead! Now has he nevertheless a mighty opinion of himself, and thinks all this wit and pretty discourse.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Lady, once more I say be civil and come kiss me; I shall ravish else, I shall ravish mightily.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well done Sir Noble, to her, never spare.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: I may be even with you though for all this Mr. Valentine: Nay, dear Sir Noble, Mr. Truman, I'le swear he'l put me into Fits.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: No, but let me salute the Hem of thy Garment. Wilt thou marry me? Kneels.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Faith Madam do, let me make the Match.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Let me die, Mr. Malagene, you are a strange man, and I'le swear have a great deal of wit. Lord, why don't you write?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Write? I thank your Ladiship for that with all my heart. No, I have a finger in a Lampoon or so sometimes, that's all.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But he can act.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: I'l swear and so he does better then any one upon our Theatres; I have seen him. Oh the English Comedians are nothing, not comparable to the French or Italian: Besides we want Poets.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Poets! why I am a Poet. I have written three Acts of a Play, and have nam'd it already. 'Tis to be a Tragedy.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh Cousin, if you undertake to write a Tragedy, take my counsel: Be sure to say soft melting tender things in it that may be moving, and make your Ladies Characters vertuous what ere you do.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Moving? why, I can never read it my self but it makes me laugh, well, 'tis the pretty'st Plot and so full of waggery.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: But Knight the Title, Knight, the Title.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Why let me see; 'Tis to be call'd, The merry Conceits of Love; or, The Life and Death of the Emperour Charles the Fifth, with the humours of his Dog Bobadillo.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But Sir Noble, this sounds more like a Comedy.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Oh, but I have resolved it shall be a Tragedy, because Bobadillo's to be kill'd in the Play. Comedy! no, I scorn to write Comedy. I know several that can squirt Comedy.—I'le tell you more of this when I am sober.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: But dear Mr. Malagene, won't you let us see you act a little something of Harlequin? I'le swear you do it so naturally, it makes me think I am at the Louvre or Whitehall all the time. Malag. acts.
Oh Lord, don't, don't neither: I'le swear you'l make me burst. Was there ever any thing so pleasant?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Was ever any thing so affected and ridiculous? Her whole life surely is a continued Scene of Impertinence. What a damn'd Creature is a decay'd woman with all the exquisite silliness and vanity of her Sex; yet none of the charms. Malag. speaks in Punchinello's voice.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: O Lord, that, that; that is a pleasure intolerable. Well, let me die if I can hold out any longer. Pray Mr. Malagene, how long have you been in love with Mrs. Tawdry the Actress?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ever since your Ladiship has been off from the hooks with Mr. Valentine. In his own voice aloud.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Uh! gud, I always thought Mr. Malagene had been better bred than to upbraid me with any such base thing to my face, what ever he might say of me behind my back: But there is no Honour, no Civility in the world, that I am satisfied of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Can your Ladiship take any thing ill from Mr. Malagene? A woman should bear with the unluckly Jerks of her Buffoon or Coxcomb, as well as with the ill manners of her Monkey sometimes: The Fools and Rascalls your Sex delights in, ought to have the priviledge of saying as well as they have of doing any thing.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Which you men of wit (as you think your selves!) are very angry you should be debarr'd of: Lord, what pity 'tis your good parts should be your misfortune.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ay Madam, I feel the curse of it: I who had just sence enough to fall in love with so much Beauty and Merit, yet could not be able to keep the Paradise I was so happily possest of.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: This malice and ill-nature shall not serve your turn; I shall know all your proceedings and intrigues with Camilla, and be reveng'd on your love to her, for all the Affronts and Injuries you have done to mine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh dear Madam, w'are utterly undone for want of your Ladiships company I'le vow. Madam Goodvile is coming with the Fiddles to wait on you here. Cuts backward.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Sir, are you a Dancing-Master? you are very nimble methinks.

sp.speaker: Caper.
sp.p: Ay Sir, I hate to stand still. But Sir Noble, I thought you had known me. I doubt you may be a little over-taken; Faith, dear heart, I am glad to see thee so merry.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Yes, I do love dearly to be drunk once a year or so, 'tis good for my bodily health. But do you never drink?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, Sir Noble, that is not my Province you know: I mind Dancing altogether.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Nor you? can't you drink, hah?

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: No, I make love and sing to Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Whores to my knowledge, errant rank common Whores. A pox on your woman of quality that you carried me to in the Mail.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Why, what was the matter Sir Noble?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: By yea and by nay, a foul over-grown Strumpet, with a running Baud instead of a Waiting-woman, a great deal of Paint, variety of old Cloaths, and nothing to eat.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Oh dear, let me die, if that was not extravagantly pleasant.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: I believe Sir Noble is much in the right, for I never came near these giddy intriguing Blockheads, but they were talking of Love and Ladies; nor ever met with a hackney stripping Whore that did not know 'em.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ned Valentine, I have a kindness to beg of you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, you may command me any thing.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why, you must know I am in love with Camilla.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Now I would have you speak to Frank Goodvile not to make love to her as he does, i'faith I can't bear it; for to tell you the truth on't, I intend to marry her; I catcht him at it but now: Faith it made my heart ake, never stir if it did not. Ex.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Introth Sir 'tis very uncivil: Truman, this Goodvile has a mind
to oblige us both; he's providing a Wife for me too as fast as he can. Camilla's his Quarrey now I understand, and by that time he has plaid as fair a Game with her as he has done with your Mistriss Victoria, I may stand fair to put in for the Rubbers.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Valentine, thou art upon too sure grounds for him there; Camilla has both too much wit and vertue, and each with as little affectation as the other.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Jack, after this I cannot but be very free with you; I know there is some love hatching between you and his Wife: both our revenge lies in thy hands, and if thou do'st not thy self and me justice, I'le disown thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: See where he comes with a heart as gay and light, as if there were nothing but honesty in it.

q.l: When Beauty can't move, and our passions grow cold,
Wine still keeps its charms, and we drink when w'are old.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: —Jack Truman, yonder have I and Victoria been laughing at thee till we were weary. She swears thou art so very modest, she would not for all the world marry thee for fear of spoiling that vertue.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Nay then I doubt I have lost her for ever; for if she complains of my modesty, she has found a fault which I never thought I had been guilty of before.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: But that is a quality which though they hate never so much in a Gallant, they are apt for many reasons to value in a Husband: Fear not, Dissimulation is the natural adjunct of their Sex; and I would no more despair of a woman, though she swore she hated me, then I would believe her though she swore she lov'd me.

div.stage: Enter Lady Squeamish, and the rest of the Company with the Fiddles.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Oh a Country Dance, a Country Dance! Mr. Caper where are you? you shall dance with Madam Camilla. Mr. Saunter wait on Victoria. Mr. Goodvile your humble Servant. Dear Mr. Truman won't you oblige me? Madam Goodvile—ha, ha, ha: I'le swear I had utterly forgotten Mr. Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your Ladiship knows me to be a civil person, if you please, I'le keep good orders. All take out the Women.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p:
Faith Ned do, and I'le keep the Musick in tune: Away Musick plays. with it; Hold, hold—what insufferable Rascals are these? why ye scurvy thrashing scraping Mongrels, ye make a worse noise then crampt Hedg-hogs. An old gouty Dancing-Master that teaches to dance with his Spectacles on, makes better Musick on his crackt Kitt—
'Sdeath ye Dogs can't you play now as a Gentleman sings? hah—

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Sir, will you never leave this nauseous humour of yours? I can never be with you but I must be forc'd to use you ill, or indure the perpetual torment of your Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Well Sir, I ha' done Sir, I ha' done: but 'tis very hard a man can't be permitted to shew his parts. 'Sdeath Frank, do'st thou think thou understand'st Musick?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Sir I understand it so well, that I won't have it interrupted in my company by you.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: I am glad on't with all my heart; I never thought you had understood any thing before.—I think there I was pretty even with you.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Sauciness and ill-manners are so much your province, that nothing but kicking is fit for you.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Sir, you may use your pleasure; but I care no more for being kickt, then you do for kicking. But prithee Frank why should you be out of humour so? The Devil take me, if I shall not give thee such a jerk presently will make thee angry indeed.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Lord, Mr. Goodvile, how can you be so ill-natur'd? I'le swear Mr. Malagene is in the right. These people have no manners in the least, play not at all to dancing: but I vow he himself sings a Tune extream prettily.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Death, Hell and the Devil, how am I teaz'd? I shall have no opportunity to pursue my business with Camilla: I must remove this troublesom Coxcomb, and that perhaps may put stop at least to her Impertinence.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
