sp.p: Mr. Truman, Mr. Goodvile, and Ladies, I beseech you do me the favour to hear Mr. Malagene sing a Scotch Song: I'le swear I am a strange Admirer of Scotch Songs, they are the pretti'st soft melting gentle harmless things—

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: By Dad, and so they are.—In January last— Sings.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Deliver us! A Scotch Song! I hate it worse then a Scotch Bagpipe, which even the Bears are grown weary of, and have better Musick. I wish I could see her Ladiship dance a Scotch Jigg to one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I must needs beg your Ladiships pardon, I have forgotten the last new Scotch Song: But if you please, I'le entertain you with one of another nature, which I am apt to believe will be as pleasant.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Let me die, Mr. Malagene, you are eternally obliging me.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Well, Madam, how like you it Madam, hah?

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Really it is very pretty now—the pretti'st odd out of the way Notes. Don't you admire it strangely?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I'le assure your Ladiship I learnt it of an Irish Musician that's lately come over, and intend to present it to an Author of my Acquaintance to put it in his next Play.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Mr. Valentine, I would have you learn it for a Serenade to your Mistriss,—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Page, Madam, is docible, and has a pretty voice, he shall learn it if you please; and if your Ladiship has any further service for him—

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Ah Lord, Wit, wit, wit, as I live! Come let's dance.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Valentine, thou art something too rough; I am afraid her Ladiship will be reveng'd; I see mischief in her eyes; 'tis safer provoking a Lancashire Witch, then an old Mistriss; and she as violent in her malice too.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Malagene, a word with you—hark ye, come hither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well Frank, what's the business now? I am clearly for mischief, shall I break the Fiddles, and turn the Rascals out of doors?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I'le be so civil to turn you out of doors. Nay, Sir, no struggling, I have Footmen within.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Whoo, prithee what's all this for? What a pox, I know my Lady well enough for a silly affected fantastical Gipsey: I did all this but o' purpose to shew her—Let me alone, I'le abuse her worse.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No Sir; but I'le take more care of your reputation, and turn you out to learn better manners. No resistance as you tender your Ears; but begon. Exit.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: So, he's gone, and now I hope I may have some little time to my self.—Fiddles strike up. Dance.

sp.speaker: Truman.
sp.p: Thus Madam you freely enjoy all the pleasures of a single life, and ease your self of that wretched formal Austerity which commonly attends a married one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Who would not hate to be one of those simpring Saints that enter into Marriage as they would go into a Nunnery, where they keep very strict to their Devotion for a while, but at last turn as errant Sinners as e're they were.

sp.speaker: Truman.
sp.p: Marriages indeed should be repair'd to as commonly Nunneries are, for handsom retreats and conveniences, not for Prisons, where those that cannot live without 'em may be safe, yet sometimes venture too abroad a little.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: But never Sir without a Lady Abbess or a Confessor at least.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Might I Madam, have the honour to be your Confessor, I should be very indulgent and lavish of Absolution to so pretty a Sinner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: See, Mr. Goodvile and Madam Camilla I believe are at shrift already.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: And poor Ned Valentine looks as pensively as if all the sins of the Company were his own.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: See Mr. Caper your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha Camilla! Sir your Servant, may I have the honour to lead this Lady a Coranto?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No Sir, Death! surely I have Fools that rest and harbour in my house, and they are a worse plague then Buggs and Mothes: shall I never be quiet?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir Noble, Sir Noble, have a care of your Mistriss! do you see there?

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Hum—ha—where? oh— Wakes and rises.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Nay, faith Madam, Harry Caper's as pretty a Fellow! 'Tis the wittiy'st Rogue: He and I laugh at all the Town. Harry, I shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Marry Sir! whom will you marry Sir? you lye. Sweet Heart come along with me, I'le marry thee my self presently.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: You, Sir Noble! —what d'ye mean? She squeaks.

sp.speaker: Sir Noble.
sp.p: Mean! honourably, honourably, I mean honourably. These are Rogues my Dear, arrant Rogues. Come along.— Ex. Sir Nob. Vict.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha, Saunter.—

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Ay Caper, ha! Let us follow this drunken Knighit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I faith, and so I will—I don't value him this! Cutts.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Well, I'le swear my Cousin Sir Noble is a strange pleasant Creature. Dear Madam, let us follow and see the sport. Mr. Truman will you walk? Oh dear, 'tis violent hot. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'le withdraw too, and at some distance observe how matters are carried between Goodvile and Camilla. Exit.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Are you then Madam resolv'd to ruine me? Why should all that stock of Beauty be thrown away on one that can never be able to deserve the gleanings of it? I love you—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And all the Sex besides. That ever any man should take such pains to forswear himself to no purpose!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Nay, then there's hopes yet, if you pretend to doubt the truth of my love; 'tis a sign you have some inclinations at least that are my Friends.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This Goodvile I see is one of those spruce polisht Fools, who have so good an opinion of themselves, that they think no woman can resist 'em, nor man of better sence despise 'em. I'le seem at present to comply, and try how far 'twill pass upon him.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Well Madam, have you consider'd on't? will the stone in your heart give way?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis full as firm and hard as ever 'twas.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: And I may then go hang or drown, or do what I will with my self? Hah?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: At your own discretion Sir, though I should be loth to see so proper a handsom Gentleman come to an ill end.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
Good charitable Creature! But Madam, know I can be reveng'd on you for this; and my revenge shall be to love you still; gloat on and loll after you where ere I see you; in all publick meetings haunt and vex you; write lamentable Sonnets on you, and so plain,
that every Fop that sings 'em shall know 'tis you I mean.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So Sir, this is something: Could not you as well have told me you had been very ill-natur'd at first? you did not know how far it might have wrought upon me; besides, 'tis a thousand times better then vowing and bowing, and making a deal of love and noise, and all to as little purpose as any thing you say else.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Right exquisite Tyrant! I'le set a watch and guard so strict upon you, you shall not entertain a well-drest Fool in private, but I'le know it; Then in a lewd Lampoon publish it to the Town; till you shall repent and curse the hour you ever saw me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ah would I could, ill-natur'd cruel man!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Hah, how's that? am I then mistaken? and have I wrong'd you all this while? I ask ten thousand pardons; curst damn'd sot that I was! I have ruin'd my self now for ever.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Well Sir, should I now forgive you all, could you consent to wrong your Lady so far? you have not yet been married a full year: How must I then suspect your love to me, that can so soon forget your faith to her?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh Madam, what do you do? the name of a Wife to a man in love is worse then cold water in a Feaver: 'Tis enough to strike the Distemper to my heart and kill me quite, my Lady quoth a!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Besides, Valentine you know is your Friend.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I grant it, he is so; A Friend is a thing I love to eat and drink and laugh withall: Nay more, I would on a good occasion lose my life for my Friend; but not my pleasure. Say where and when it shall be?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Never, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: You must by and by when 'tis a little darker, in the left-hand Walk in the lowest Garden.

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: I won't promise you; can't you trust my good nature?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Charming Creature! I do: Now if I can but make up the Match between Truman and Victoria, my hopes are compleated.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Haste! haste! away Sir, I see Valentine coming.— Ex. Goodv.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Madam, you are extreamly merry; I am glad Mr. Goodvile has left you in so good a humour.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ay Sir, and what may please you more, he is parted hence in as good a humour as he has left me here.

div.stage: Enter Lady Squeamish, Bridget at the Door.

sp.speaker: L. Sq.
sp.p: Valentine and Camilla alone together! Now for an opportunity to be reveng'd! ah how I love malice!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ungratefull'st of women!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
Foolishest of men! Can you be so very silly to be jealous? for I find you are so: What have you ever observ'd since first your knowledge
of me that might perswade you I should ever grow fond of a man, as notoriously false to all Women, as you are unworthy of me? Aside.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Has Valentine been false to her too? nay, then there is some pleasure left yet, to think I am not the onely Woman that has suffer'd by his baseness.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What then, I'll warrant you were alone together half an hour only for a little harmless raillery or so; an honour I could never obtain without hard suit and humble supplication.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Alas! how very Politick you are grown! you would pretend displeasure to try your power. No—I shall henceforth think you never had a good opinion of me, but that your Love was at first as ill grounded as your fantasticall Jealousy is now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What specious pretence can you urge? (I know a Woman can never be without one;) come, I am easy and good natur'd, willing to believe and be deceiv'd: —what, not a word?

sp.speaker: Camill.
sp.p: Though I can hardly descend to satisfy your distrust, for which I hardly value you and almost hate you; yet to torment you farther, know I did discourse with him, and of love too; nay more, granted him an appointment, but one I never meant to keep, and promised it onely to get rid of him. This is more then I am oblig'd to tell you, but that I wanted such an opportunity as this to check your pretences, which I found grew too unruly to be kept at a distance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tho' I had some reason to be in doubt, yet this true resentment and just proceeding has convinc'd me: For Goodvile is a man I have little reason to trust, as will appear hereafter, and 'twas my knowledge of his baseness made me run into so mean a distrust of you: But forgive me this, and when I fail again discard me for ever.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Yes: But the next time I shall happen to discourse with a Gentleman in private, I shall have you listning at the door or eves-dropping under the window. What, distrust your friend the honourable worthy Mr. Goodvil! — fie, how can you be so ungenerous?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: There is not such another Hypocrite in the World: He never made Love but to delude, nor Friendship but for his ends: — Even his own Kinswoman, and charge Victoria he has long since corrupted, and now would put her on his best Friend Truman for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I cannot but laugh to think, how easily he swallow'd the cheat: He could not be more transported at possession, then he was with expectation, and he went away in a greater Triumph then if he had conquer'd the Indies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where did you promise him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: In the left hand walk in the lower Garden.

sp.speaker: L. Squ
sp.l: So in the left hand walk in the lower Garden: I heard that. Aside.
But Mr. Valentine you may chance to meet another there:
Let me die, this is pleasant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And when?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Anon when it begins to grow dark.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Enough, I know the time and place; and Madam Camilla, I shall make bold to cheat you of your Lover to night. Alas poor inconsiderable Creature, how this makes me loath her!

sp.speaker: Camil.
sp.p: Now would this News be more welcom to her Ladishp Madam Squeamish, then a new Fashion, a new Dance, or a new Song: How many Visits would she make on the occasion! not a Family in Town would be at rest for her, till she had made it a Jest. From the Mother of the Maids, to the Atturney's Wife in Holborn.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But for some private reasons I would have kept it from her, and from Madam Goodvile too. There are Affairs to be carry'd on to Night, which the least Accident may interrupt.—Besides, I have thought upon't, and will so contrive the matter, that Goodvile shall keep his Assignation, and her Ladiship her self supply the place of the much expected charming Camilla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But would you Sir do me such an Injury as to make me break my word with Mr. Goodvile? that were inhumane.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good Conscionable Creature have patience, and don't you think of paying Debts too fast, there's an Account yet between you and I which must be made even; and I think I had best secure it now I have you in my custody.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Ay but Sir, if I part with any thing, I shall expect to have something to shew for't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, if I don't offer as lusty security and conditions as any man, let me lose all I lay claim to, that's fair. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: So, are they gone? Now let me but live if this Intrigue be not extreamly surprizing. Bridget go home, and fetch me the Morning-Gown I had last made in imitation of Camilla's, for perhaps I shall go a Masquerading to Night, or it may be not, but fetch it nevertheless.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam, won't the other serve? you may remember you left it at my Lady Foplove's t'other Night; that's nearer.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Impertinent Creature! and would'st thou have me appear in it twice? Do as I bid you, I say; And d'ye hear, bring me a Mask with an Amber-Bead, for I fear I may have Fits to Night.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I never knew her without fantastical ones I am sure, for they cost me many a weary Errand. Ex.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh my dear Victoria! the most unlookt for happiness! the pleasant'st accident! the strangest discovery! the very thought of it were enough to cure melancholy. Valentine and Camilla, Camilla and Valentine, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Dear Madam, what is it so transports you?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis too precious to be communicated: hold me, hold me, or I shall dye with laughter—ha, ha, ha, Camilla and Valentine, Valentine and Camilla—ha ha ha.—O dear, my heart's broke.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Good Madam refrain your mirth a little, and let me know the Story, that I may have a share in it.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: An Assignation! an Assignation to Night in the lower Garden. —By strong good fortune I over-heard it all just now—but to think on the pleasant consequence that will happen, drives me into an excess of joy beyond all sufferance.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Madam, in all probability the pleasant'st consequence is like to be thei • s if any bodies, and I cannot guess how it should touch your Ladiship in the least.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh Lord, how can you be so dull? why, at the very hour and place appointed will I meet Valentine in Camilla's stead, before she can be there her self; then when she comes expose her infamy to all the world, till I have throughly reveng'd my self for all the base Injuries her Lover has done to me.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: But Madam, can you indure to be so malicious?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: That, that's the dear pleasure of the thing; for I vow I'd sooner die ten thousand deaths, if I thought I should hazard the least temptation to the prejudice of my honour.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: But why should your Ladiship run into the mouth of danger? Who knows what scurvy lurking Devil may stand in readiness and seize your Vertue before you are aware of him?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Temptation? No I d have you know I scorn Temptation: I durst trust my self in a Convent amongst a Kennel of Cramm'd Friers: Besides that ungrateful ill-bredfellow Valentine is my mortal aversion: more odious to me then foul Weather on a May-Day, or ill smell in a Morning.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Nay, now Madam you are too violent.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Too violent! I would not keep a waiting-woman that should commend any one thing about him: Dear Victoria urge nothing in his behalf, for if you do, you lose my friendship for ever: Tho' I swear he was a fine Person once, before he was spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I am sure your Ladiship had the best share in his spoiling then. Aside.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: No, were I inclin'd to entertain addresses, I assure I need not want for Servants: For I swear I am so perplext with Billet Deux every Day, I know not which way to turn my self: Besides there is no fidelity, no honour in Mankind: Oh dear Victoria! whatever you do, never let Love come near your heart: Though really I think true Love is the greatest pleasure in the World.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Would I had never known Love: My honour had not then lain at the mercy of so ungrateful a Wretch as Goodvile, who now has certainly abandon'd and forgotten me.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Well, certainly I am the most unsteady restless humoursome woman breathing: Now am I so transported at the thoughts of what I have design'd, that I long till the hour comes, with more Impatience then — I'l swear I know not what to say — Dear Victoria ten thousand adieus — Wish me good success — Yet now I think on't I'l stay a little longer — I'l swear I must not neither — Well! I'l go— No, I'l stay — Well, I am resolvd neither to stand still — sit still — nor lie still — nor have one thought at rest — till the business be over. — I'l swear I am a strange Creature. Exit L. Squ.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Farewel Whirligig.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Victoria here! To meet with an old Mistress when a man is in pursuit of a fresh one, is a worse Omen then a Hare in a Journey.
I'l step aside this way till she's past me, so, farewel Fubb.
Now for the lovely kind yielding Camilla! How I long for the happy hour! Swelling burning breasts, dying eyes, balmy lips, trembling joints, millions of kisses and unspeakable joys wait for me.
Well, Gentlemen! Now you have left the Ladies, I hope there may be room near your hearts for a Bottle or two.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Dear Goodvil thou art too pow'rful to be deny'd any thing. 'Tis a fine cool Evening, and a swift Glass or two now were seasonable and refreshing, to wash away the Toil and Fatigue of the Day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: After a man has been disturb'd with the publick Impertinences and Follies he meets withall abroad, he ought to recompence himself with a Friend and a Bottle in private at Night.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Spoken like men that deserve the life you enjoy: I'l in before and put all things in readiness. Ex. Goodvil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This worthy Person for his honesty and sobriety, would have made a very good Dutch Burgomaster: But he is as damnable an English Friend and Gentleman as one would wish to meet withal.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Valentine, thou art too much concerned at him: Methinks Camilla's Justice and the pleasant Cheat she has put upon him, should rather make thee despise and laugh at him as I do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Truman, thou indeed hast reason: And when I shall know the happy success of the revenge thou hast in store for him, I may do my Self and Him that Justice as scorn him, but am too angry yet.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Then to give thee ease (for I dare trust thee) know this very night I also have an Assignation with his Wife in the Grotto at the upper end of the Garden, the opposite walk to that where he expects to meet Camilla.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then I am at rest, let's in. I have nothing else to do but take care so to finish him, as that you shall fear no Interruption: At least he will be fo full of his expectation of Camilla, that he'l never dream in what posture his own affairs stand in another place.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Away then: and may good luck attend us: Er'e yet two hours are past, his Wife's my own methinks already in that secure dark private Grotto.

q.l: Close in my arms, and languishing she lies,
With dying looks, short breath, and wishing eyes;
And the supine dull Cuckold nothing spies. Exeunt.

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT. SCENE Night-garden.
div.stage: Enter Goodvile at one Door, Mrs. Goodvile and Lettice following her at the other.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: SO, I think I came off in good time: hold! now for Camilla, by Jove I think I am little better then drunk. Hah! who's there, Victoria as I live; nay it must be she as I said before. The poor Gipsy's jealous; has had some intimation of my appointment with Camilla: I'll loof off and observe which way she steers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Good.
sp.p: Lettice I fear that's Mr. Goodvil's Voice, what ever you doe, if any cross accident happens, be sure you call me Victoria.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye aye, 'tis Victoria! Vigilant Devil! but I'll take this way, and wait at the lower end of the Walk.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Lettice look well round you that no body see us, and then follow me.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Thus far all is well: how I pity poor Valentine! yonder is he plying Bumpers as they call 'em, more furiously then a Foreign Minister that comes into England to drink for the Honour of his Country. I have waited something long though, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Sir, your Servant Lettice.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: My little good natur'd Agent is it you? where's thy Lady? she's too cruell to let a poor Lover languish here so long in expectation: it looks as if she rather meant to make a tryall of my Patience, then my Love: is she coming?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Well, I swear (as my Lady Squeamish says) you are a strange Creature. But I'll goe and tell her: Though I'll vow I utterly disowne having any hand in this Business; and if any ill comes of it 'tis none of my fault.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: No no, not in the least, prithee dispatch. How's this! more company! who comes there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Jack Truman, your friend Valentine.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: My dear encourager of Iniquity! what news? Where's Goodvile?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No matter for Goodvile! here comes your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Now, now, now, what the Devil ailes me? how I shall quake and tremble?
Madam, dear Madam, where are you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, is't your voice? Lettice, you may goe in again if you will.— Ex. Lettice.
Well, Sir, I'll vow Sir, had it not been that I hate to break my word, I would not have ventur'd abroad this cold damp evening for a World.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Madam, whilst you are in my possession, no cold shall hurt you: come, shall we withdraw to the Grotto?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Withdraw to the Grotto? bless me, Sir! what do you mean? I'll swear you make my Heart ake.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Oh Madam! I have the best Cure for the passion of the Heart in the World. I have try'd it Madam, 'tis Probatum: come, come, let's retire,— do, make a disturbance and ruine your self and me, do!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Nay, I'll swear, Sir, you are insufferably rude; you had best make a noise and Alarm my Husband, you had, for hang me I shall cry out.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: No, no, I'm sure you won't complain before you are hurt; and I'll use you so gently — hark! — don't you hear, there's some body coming.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Where, where, where? If we are seen we are undone for ever: well, I'll never give you such an advantage again.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: I'm sure you would not, if I should let slip this. Come, come, delayes are dangerous, and I can endure 'em no longer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Ah Lord you kill me! —what will become of me— ah — Carries her in.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, faith, Madam, your condition is something desperate that's certain. 'Tis a pretty employment I am like to have here; but it is for the sake of my Friend and my Revenge: and two dearer Arguments there cannot be to perswade me to any thing.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: So, Jack Truman and Madam Goodvile have ordered matters pretty well; I'll say that for my Kinswoman, she lays about her handsomly; but certainly I hear another Voice this way; I'll withdraw once again, there may be more sport yet,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That should be Goodvile: I'll step behind this Tree, and see how he and her Ladyship behave themselves. This is like to be a night of as civil business as I have known a great while.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Death, and the Devil! how that puny Rogue Valentine has souced me? if I should have overstay'd the time now and mist of my appointment with Camilla — Truman is reel'd home that's certain, and Valentine I believe has follow'd him by this time. Camilla, dear, lovely, kind, tender, melting Camilla, where art thou?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: That must be Valentine, nay, I am sure it is he! how sneakingly will he look when he shall find his mistake? but I'll take care if possible that no such thing shall happen, so mine be the pleasure, and Camilla's the scandall; I'll rush by him through the Walk into the Wilderness.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: That must be she, how swiftly she flew along, as if she fear'd to be too late, loosely attired and fit for Joys! Now all the power of Love and good fortune direct me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So, thanks to our Stars, he is safe; though a Pox on't, methinks this dry pimping is but a scurvy employment: had I but a Sister or Kinswoman of his to keep doing withall, there were some comfort in it,— but here comes Truman and the Lady, I must not be seen. Ex.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: You shall not goe: Come but back a little, I have something more to tell you that nearly concerns us both: besides, Mr. Goodvil's in the Garden, and if he should chance to meet us, what excuse could we make to him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: But will you promise me Victoria shall never rob me of your Heart? She does not deserve it I am sure half so well as I.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Kind tender hearted Creature I know it: nor shall she ever come so near it, as to know that I have one: —alas! we talk too long, Noise. I hear company coming, we shall be surpriz'd, and disappointed, and then I am undone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I'll swear you make me tremble every Joynt of me: what would you have me doe?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: See, see, who are yonder. Exeunt Truman and Mrs. Goodvile.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: What a feast of delight have I had! surely she was born only to make me happy! her naturall and unexperienced Tenderness exceeded practis'd Charms: —Dear blest lovely Camilla, oh! my Joys!

sp.speaker: L Squ.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: How's this? my Lady Squeamish! —Death and the Devil.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Truly sweet Mr. Valentine the same: Now, Sir, I hope— Ugh gad! Mr. Goodvile! They stare at each other.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Have I been mumbling an Old Kite all this while instead of my Young Partridge? a Pox o' my depraved palate that could distinguish no better.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Lord Mr. Goodvile, what ayles you! —this was an unexpected Adventure; but let let me dye, it is very pleasant: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: A Pox on the pleasures, and you too I say.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: This malicious Devil Camilla has overreached me: —Well Mr. Goodvile you are the worthyest person; —had I an only Daughter, I durst trust her with you, you are so very civil: —well, Innocence is the greatest happiness in the World.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Right Madam, it is so, and you know we have been very innocent; done no harm in the world, not we.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: The Censorious World if they knew of this Accident, I know would be apt enough to speak reproachfully; but so long as I my self am satisfyed in the Integrity of my Honour, the World is a thing I defy and scorn.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Very Philosophically spoken: —But, Madam, so long as the World is to be a stranger to our Happiness, why should we deny our selves the second pleasure of Congratulation?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Alas, alas, Mr. Goodvile, you cannot say that you have had the least advantage over my frailty: well, what might have happened if the strict severity of both our vertues had not secured us?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: This affected Impudence of hers is beyond all the impertinence I ever knew her guilty of: —Vertue with a Pox! I think I have reason to know her pretty well, and the Devil of any Vertue found I about her.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: But dear Sir, let us talk no more of it: though I am extreamly mistaken if I saw not Mr. Valentine enter the Garden before me, and am as much mistaken if a Lady was not with him too.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Hell and Confusion! that must be Victoria: I thought indeed I saw her, but being hot-headed, and apprehending she came with a malicious design of discovering me, avoided her, —false to me with Valentine?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: I'll swear Mr. Goodvile I have long suspected an Intrigue between you and Madam Victoria, and this Jealousy has confirmed me, and I would not for all the World but have known it. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Death Madam! this is beyond all sufferance:—disappointed, and jilted by Camilla! abused by Victoria! and with Valentine too, Trumans friend, whom I thought should have marry'd her! —
Shame and Infamy light upon the whole Sex! may the best of 'em be ever suspected, and the most cautious always betray'd.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Goodvile be patient: let me dye, you are enough to frighten our whole Sex from ever loving or trusting men again: — Lord, I would not be poor Madam Victoria, to gain an Empire, I'll swear if you are not more moderate, you'll discompose me strangely: — how my heart beats!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Patience! preach it to a galled Lyon: —no, I am sure she is not far off, and I will find her; surprize her in the midst of her Infamy and prostitution; —'Sdeath Madam, let me goe.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: I will not part with you, you ill-natur'd Creature; you shall not goe: —I vow, I'll cry a Rape if you offer to stir: —oh my heart, here's Malagene.

div.stage: Enter Malagene Singing Frank, Frank, Frank, &c.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Why how now Frank, what a pox, out of humour? Why Madam, what have you done to him; what have you done to him Madam? Lord how he looks! —why Frank I say, prethee bear up.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Hark you Dog fool Coxcomb, hold that impertinent impudent Tongue of yours or I'll cut it out; 'Sdeath you Buffoon I will.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No, but hark you dear heart, good words, good words do you hear, or I shall publish, by my Soul Joy, I shall.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: How am I continually plagu'd with Rogues and Owles! I'll set my house o'fire rather then have it haunted and pester'd by such Vermine.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Faith Frank doe: I have not seen a House o'fire this great while, it would be a pretty Frollick, prethee let us about it presently.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Goodvile you shall be perswaded: don't run your self into danger thus rashly.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Do you hear then, Monsieur Pimponio, as you expect to live a quiet hour, run in and call for some Lights, and return with 'em instantly.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Say no more Dear Heart; I'll doe't: if mischief comes not of this the Devil's in't—but dear Frank stay till I come again, I'll be back in a Trice; take t'other turn with her Ladyship into the Wilderness; or any thing. Ex. Malag.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Let me not live, this Mr. Malagene is a very obliging Person, and methinks Mr. Goodvile you use him too severely.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I wish Madam he may deserve that Character of you: he is one of those Worldlings you were speaking of, that are apt to talk reproachfully: and I believe knows all that has past between us to night, for he has a shrewd discerning Judgment in these matters.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Lord Mr. Goodvile what can he say of me? I defye even Envy it self to doe me or my Honour any prejudice: though I wish I had let this Frollick alone to night.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Frollick with a Pox! —if these be her Frollicks, what the Devil is she when she is in earnest? Oh he returns with the Lights: —look who are these? by Heaven the same.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Gently, gently Madam, for fear of an Ambuscade; I wonder I hear nothing from Ned Valentine since?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Godv.
sp.p: See, see Sir, here's Mr. Goodvile: haste, haste down the other Walk, or we are ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Fear not, trust all to my Conduct. Exeunt.

div.stage: As Mrs. Goodvile is going away, Goodvile catches hold of her Gown — she claps on her Masque.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Stay Madam Victoria, nay you may stay, 'tis in vain to flye, I have discovered all your falshood, I have: was mine a passion to be thus abused? I who have given you all my Heart! perfidious false Woman!—is your Lover too ashamed or afraid to shew himself? where is he? why comes he not forth?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Here I am Sir.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
Hah! Truman!
Mrs. Goodv. gets loose and Ex.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Yes Sir, the same: ready both to acknowledge and justify my being here with Victoria, which I thought Sir, might have been allowed without any offence to Mr. Goodvile. That she is Innocent as to any thing on my part, I am ready with my Sword to make good; but Sir, I wear it too to doe my own Honour Justice, and to demand of you on what grounds you appear so highly concern'd for a Woman you were pleased to commend to your friend for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Concern'd Sir! have I not reason to be concern'd for the Honour of my Family? for a Kinswoman under my charge to be abroad and alone with a Gentleman at this unseasonable hour, might alarm a Man less tender of his reputation then I am.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir, this excuse won't serve my turn; nor am I so blind as not to be sensible (which I before suspected,) that Victoria has been long your Mistress: — A pox of the Honour of your Family, you had given her all your Heart you said; and your Passion was not a thing to be thus abused: nor Sir, is my Honour.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No, but dear Jack Truman, thou art my Friend.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p:
You would have made me believe so indeed; but the daubing was too course, and the Artificiall Face appeared too plain: —One would have thought Sir, that you who keep a generall Decoy here for Fools and
Coxcombs, might have found one to have recompenced a Cast Mistress withall, and not have indeavour'd the betraying the Honour of a Gentleman and your Friend: but Sir, I am glad I have heard it from your own mouth: I hope it will not be esteemed much ill-nature in me, if worthy Mr. Malagene and I, joyn forces to publish a little, as he calls it.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Faith Jack Truman, with all my heart; now I have him on my side, I dare say any thing—Frank Goodvile—pugh.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Sir, I shall require a better account of this hereafter.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Lord Mr. Truman, what ayles Mr. Goodvile? how happen'd this difference? —I'll swear I am strangely surprized.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Your Ladyship I suppose can best give an account how matters are with him: I am apt to believe he has been very free with you.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Dear Sir, what do you mean? I'll swear you are a scandalous Person.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Sir, since you are so rough, be pleased not to concern your self with the Honour of this Lady; you may have enough to doe if you dare justify your own to morrow.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: If I dare? —nay Sir, since you question it, I'll convince you presently; —Draw. They fight.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what's the matter here? —Jack Truman, Frank Goodvile, for shame put up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Where is this perfidious false man? where is Mr. Goodvile? So Sir, I have found now the Originall of all my Misfortunes: I have a Rivall it seems; Victoria, the happy Victoria, possesses all my Joys: what, have you been fighting too for the Honour of your Mistress? —here, come kill me: would I had been lain in my Grave, e're I had known thy odious polluted Bed.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I thought she had been in her Chamber this hour at least: —'Tis true my Dear, I must own a kindness for Victoria, as my Kinswoman; but—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: How! dare you own it? and to my face too? matchless Impudence! let me come at him, that I may tear out those hot lascivious glowing Eyes that wander after every Beauty in their way: —oh! that I could blast him with a look! —was my Love so despicable to be abandon'd for Victoria's! The thought of it makes me mad: I'll indure it no longer, I will have Revenge or I will dye! Oh!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Delicate Dissimulation! How I love her!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Dear Madam hear me speak—Madam, I say that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I know you cannot want an excuse, Dissimulation and Falshood have been your practice: — But that you should wrong me with Victoria, a Woman that for the sake of your Relation I had made my Friend, (for every thing that was ally'd to you was dear to me,) is an injury so great, that it distracts my Reason: — I could pardon any thing but my wrong'd Love.—Let me be gone; send me to a Nunnery; confine me to a charnel House, Vile Ungrateful Wretch, any thing but thy presence 〈◊〉 can endure.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Is there every way so damn'd a Creature as a Wife? —
Lord Madam, do you know what you do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv,
sp.p: I'le warrant it, you would perswade me I am mad: — Would I had been born a Fool! I might then have been happy: Patiently have pass'd over the many tedious Nights I have indured in your absence: Contented my self with Prayers for your safety.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Oh! Lord, Prayers!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: When you in the very instant were languishing in the Arms of a Prostitute.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, I thought you had been in your Chamber now: — Curse on her what shall I do!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign you believed me safe enough; you would not certainly else have had the Impudence to have brought a new Mistress under my Nose: — I see there how guilty she stands; — have you a stomach so hot that it can digest Carrion that has been buzz'd about and blown upon by all the Flies in the Town? Or was it the fantasticalness of your Appetite, to try how so course a Dish would relish, after being cloyed with better feeding? — Nay Sir I have been informed of all. —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Has then your Vertuous Ladiship been taking a little Love and Air with Mr. Goodvil this Evening? To La. Squeamish.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Well, she has dealt with the Devil that's certain: —A Pox on t, I see there's no living for me in this side of the World: — Go, let the Coach be made ready; I'le into the Country.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Nay Sir I know my presence has always been uneasie to you; Day and Night you are from me, or if ever you come home, 'tis with an aking Head, and heavy Heart, which Victoria only has Charms enough to Cure. This in the first year of our Marriage! Nay and to own it! Proclaim your own Falshood and my disgraceful Injury in the face of the World, when Malagene too, the Trumpet of all the Scandal in Town was by, to be a Witness: — 'Twas very discreetly done, and doubtless will be a Secret long.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Whirr, — Nay since it is so, why the Devil should I strive to smother my good Actions? — Well, if you will have it so, Madam Victoria has been my Mistress, is my Mistress, and shall be my Mistress, and what a Pox would you have more? and so God b'ye to you.

div.stage: Enter Sir Noble, Caper, and Saunter.

sp.speaker: S. Nob.
sp.p: How's this! Who's that speaks dishonourably of my Love, and Lady that shall be, Victoria? Before George she's a Queen, and whoever says to the contrary, I'le first make him eat my Sword, and then beat out his Teeth with the Hilts of it.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh! Dear Madam, yonder's all the Town in Musquerade; won't you walk in? they'l be gone if they see no Company: Jack Truman, dear Jack prithee go and take one frisk: — As I hope to be saved, there are Three or Four the finest Ladies, the delicatest shaped Women; I am sure I know 'em all.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sir I wish you good Fortune, but I dare not venture, you know my Temper; I shall be very boisterous and mistake 'em for Whores, though if they be of your Acquaintance, I know they must be of Quality.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I Gad, and so they are, but Mum for that: — One of 'em is she that gave me this Ring; and the other presented me with a Gold enamelled Watch could not cost less than Thirty Guinnies: — Trifles Jack which I have the Fortune to meet withal sometimes.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Nay Sir you must not come off so, — Victoria your Mistress!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and how are you concern'd at it?

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Nay Sir I can be as civil as any body, — Victoria your Mistress!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: 'S death you Coxcomb, mind your singing, do you hear? and play the Fool by your self, or —

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Sing Sir? so I can, Fa La Da La La, &c. Victoria your Mistress!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I say my Mistress.

sp.speaker: S. Nob.
sp.p: Ounds, then Draw.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hold Sir Noble, you are too furious; what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Why how now Saunter? How dost doe dear Heart? — Sir, this Gentleman's my Friend, and —

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Was ever man so overwhelm'd with Fools and Blockheads? Why you ill-ordered Addle-pated wadling brace of Puppies: — You Fool, in the first place sing and be safe, — and you slight Grashopper dance and divert me: Dance Sirrah, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Dance Sir? and so I think I can Sir, and Fence, and play at Tennis, and make Love, and fold up a Billet Doux, or any thing better then you Sir: Dance quoth a — there Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Nay Sir Noble, not only so, but own'd and boasted of it to my Face: Told me —

sp.speaker: S. Nob.
sp.p: Soul of my Honour, 'tis unpardonable: and I'le eat his Heart for it.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Dear raw Head and bloody Bones be patient a little: — See see you Beagles, Game for you, fresh Game; that great Towser has started it already, on, on, on, halloo, halloo, halloo.

div.stage: Thrusts 'em at his Wife, and Exit.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: But Dear Mr. Caper, Masqueraders did you say! I'le swear I'le among 'em, shall I not have your Company? Oh! Dear Masqueraders! I'le vow I can stay no longer. Exit hastily.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Curse on her, she's gone and has prevented me: — Caper, Saunter, did you not hear my Lady call you? She's gone to the Masqueraders, for shame follow her; she'l take it ill you did not wait on her.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Faith Caper and so she will. Well I am resolved to Marry Victoria for fear of the worst:— Madam your most Devoted Servant: I hope our difference with Mr. Goodvil to Night —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Dear Sir it needs no excuse.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: My resentments Madam —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You are too Ceremonious Gentlemen, and my Lady will fear she has lost you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Dear Jack, as I told thee before, I must bring thee acquainted with those Ladies.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Prithee put on a Masque and come among us, Jack, Faith do.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sirs, I'le wait on you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Dear Soul Adieu. Embracing him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: These Coxcombs, Madam, came in a good time, they were never seasonable before.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Diseases and Visitations are necessary sometimes to sweep away the noisome Crowds that infest and incumber the World.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As I have often said I must publish, I must spread; and so God b'ye to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, yonder's my Master raving for his Coach: Sayes he'l into the Country presently: Has given order to disperse the Company, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Let him go, 'twere pity to hinder him: — ha! ha! ha! into the Country? I'd as soon believe he would turn Capuchin.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But Madam 'twas inhumanly done, to come your self upon him: One would have thought that I had used him bad enough, for the wise mistake he made of Victoria.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I would not have miss'd it for the World: Now would he come on his Knees for Composition; and if I do not bring him to it within these four hours —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why Madam, what will you do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Put on all the notorious Affectations and ridiculous Impertinencies that ever the most eminent of our Sex have studied, or the Coxcombs of your Sex admired; then of a sudden seem to grow fond of both those Clincant Fools, which I am sure he of all things loaths; Yet do it too so forc'dly, that he himself shall find it only intended to give him vexation.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Have you then malitiously designed in spight of Nature, to keep me constant?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Which you will be sure to be! —

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: A Dozen new fresh young unseen Beauties, and the Devil himself in the Rear of 'em, cannot make me otherwise: I never really Lov'd or Liv'd till now: There is nothing I'de not wish to be, except the very Husband himself, rather then lose you.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, Ned, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Treason Truman; your being here with Mrs. Goodvil I fear is discovered; I heard some such thing whisper'd among the Masqueraders, and Goodvil himself seems suddenly alter'd; I would advise you to come and shew your self, and make the best on't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Let me alone; I'le secure all I'le warrant you: I'm sure he can have no positive proofs: I'le instantly go and put all things in a confusion, contradict all the orders he has given for going into the Country; shut up my self in my Chamber, and not hear a word of him till he comes upon submission:— Lettice follow me to my Chamber presently.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Right exquisite Woman and Wife, good Luck attend thee.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Well, my Lady certainly of a young Lady knows her business, and understands the managing of a Husband the best of any Woman in the World: I'le swear she is an ingenious person: Forty Ladies now at such an accident, would have been hurried and afraid, and the poor waiting Woman must have been sent forward and backward, and backward and forward to hearken and inquire, but she shows all her changes in a motion.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: How now Lettice? where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Within Sir, in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Sir she commanded me to follow her thither but now.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Is she alone there?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Ay Sir, I'le assure you she seldome desires Company: — But I must hasten aad follow her.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Stay a little, are you sure she was in the House, before this disturbance hapned in the Garden?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p:
Sure Sir! why I my self was at the Chamber window with her when first she heard you exclaim against Madam Victoria! Poor Creature, I was afraid she would have fallen down dead on the floor: I catch'd her in my Arms, beg'd of her on my knees not to 〈◊〉 out; but she would hear nothing, but spight of force broke from me, and came hither with all that
Impatience and Rage, the too sensible resentment of your unkindness had rais'd in her.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Get you in presently, do you hear? and take no notice of what I have said to you as you tender your well-being.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Yes Sir: — But if I conceal a word of it, may I never serve London Lady again, but be condemn'd to be a Country-Chamber-Maid, and kill fleas as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: If I should have been in the wrong all this while, and mistaken my own Dear Wife for Victoria! — Ah! Curse on this hot head of mine! Pox on't it is impossible! Yet that mischievous Rogue Malagene was all the while in the Garden, and he has been at his Doubts and Ambiguities, and may-be's with me: — By this Light I am a Cuckold, an Arrant Rank stinking Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: What will become of me! whither shall I fly to hide my misfortune? Oh! that I might never see the Light again, but be for ever conceal'd in these shades.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Dear Victoria is it you? be free with me; were you really in the Garden before, to night, or no?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: I have not been out of the House since it was dark, till this minute, nor had I come hither now, but that I am destitute where to conceal my self from the malitious Eyes and Tongues of those, to whom your baseness has given an opportunity of Triumphing over my Misfortune and ruin'd Honour.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Be not so outragious; I'le reconcile all yet.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Which way is it possible? By to Morrow morning your very Footmen will have it in their mouths; and Malagene that keeps an Office of Intelligence for all the Scandal in Town, will be spreading it among his Coffee-House Companions, and at the Play whisper it to the Orange Women, who shall make a fulsome jest of it to the next Coxcomb that comes in half drunk, to Loll and Play, and be nauseously lewd with 'em in publick.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I tell thee it shall not be; Malagene's my Creature, or at least, henceforth I'le make him so; I have reasons for it, and to believe also that my Wife, my own delicate damn'd Wife, was the same I mistook for you in the Garden to night.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I was at the same time to see for her in her Chamber, and she was not there; but cannot believe her in the least guilty of what you seem to accuse her of.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Confound her: — She's an exquisite Jilt, thorough paced, and practised in all the cunning Arts and Sleights of Falshood: 'Sdeath how I could mince her! But here comes Malagene, he knows all, and I'le make him confess all, or I'le murd • r him.
Well Sir what say you to this matter?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith Bully I think my dear Kinswoman has maul'd you to some purpose; I'le say this for her, she has the true blood of the Malagene's in her: To lol dara lal, &c.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: What is't you mean Fool? Be plain, and unfold your self.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why you must know Frank, having a particular esteem for my Family, (the nearest Relation of which, I would go Fifty Miles to see hang'd) I do think her as very a— But no more, — Mum dear Heart, Mum, I say.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: What's that you say Sir? what do you think my Wife?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ay, what, Frank? what? now.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Nay Sir, that you must resolve me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why then I'le tell the Frank; dost thou really think I love thee?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I know you'l say so Sir, because you fear me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then prithee do so much as lend me ten Guinies for a day or two.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh Sir to the purpose, to the purpose; be brief.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay then, Mum I say again.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Will you never leave vexing me with your Impertinence? Must I be always forc'd to use you ill, to bring you to good manners?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Faith Child, I am loth to make mischief; I have been a very wicked ill-natur'd Impudent Fellow, that's the truth on't: But I find I lose my self by it: The very Poets themselves that were wont to stand in awe of me, care not a louse for me now; and there's not a common Whore in Town, but calls me Rogue and Rascal to my Face, as Impudently, as if I were her Pimp.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Therefore Sir resolve to turn honest, and be just to your Friend.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: The Devil take me Frank, if thou art not a very Impertinent Fellow: — Know! why who should know better than yourself? Hah!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Here are Five Guinies for you, upon Condition you make a full and true Relation of all you have discover'd this night.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I'le do't; down with your dust.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: What will not this Rakehel do to borrow money? I knew him make Love to a Chamber-Maid till he had borrowed Five Pounds of her at half a Crown a time.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well Frank Goodvil, you may think as you please of me; but hang me like a Dog if I am not a very honest Fellow in my heart:— You would have me deal freely with you, you say, in this Business?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I would so Sir, or I shall deal very roughly with you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: And you lent me these Five Guinies to that purpose?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: You are much in the right Sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Then to make short of the matter; thou art as arrant a poor silly Cuckold as one would wish to drink withal, and Confound me if I shall not be asham'd of thy Company.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Confounded VVhore! — Oh for a Legion of Devils to hurry her to Hell, and that I had but the driving of 'em!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nay nay Man, since 'tis so, never be angry for the matter: what a Pox, you thought to put the Mistress upon Truman! Truman has put the Cuckold upon you; Valentine has been Pimp in the business; and the Devil take me if I don't think, my self the honestest Fellow amongst you.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Now Sir consider what a wretched thing you have made me.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No more; I'm thine, and here I seal my heart to thee forever.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Well Frank can I serve thee any further in this Business?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: That Sir, is as time shall try: And to convince you how fit I think you for my purpose, I know you are a Rascal not to be trusted: Therefore observe it, if you offer to stir beyond the Limits I set you, at that very instant I'le Murder you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Prithee talk not to me of Limits and Murdering, I hope you take me Sir (under the Rose) for no Fool: And what a Pox do you think to make of me?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: A Spaniel to Hunt and Set the Game I mean to take: Oh! Malagene, there will be mischief Malagene, and new ripe fresh Scandal to treat of: I know it is an Office thou lovest, and therefore do it to obligethee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: I'Faith, and so I do with all my heart: But Frank I don't know how this Business will be brought about well: I have promised to meet Two or Three hearty old Souls to Morrow at Dinner, to Swear and Drink, and talk Baudy and Treason together for an hour or Two, they are all Atheists, and very honest Fellows.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh Sir you may be hang'd in good time: But for this present occasion I must use you: Victoria, do you with all your utmost Art dissemble but the least knowledg of what has happen'd to night: And Sir do you keep still that lying snearing ugly merry Face which you always wear when you design Mischief: I'le pretend this morning to pursue my Design of going into the Country; then when they are in the height of their pleasures and assurance of their safety, return and surprize 'em.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: But do you believe Sir that you can utterly abandon all sense of your past Love and Tenderness for a Woman, who has been so Dear to you? You will be apt to relapse again.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I will sooner return to my Vomit: I am rather glad of the occasion to be rid of so troublesome uneasie a burden: A Wife after a Year, like a Garment that has been worn too long, hangs loose and awkardly on a Man, and grows a Scandal to him that wears it.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: But can you then resolve to quit and disown her for ever?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
For ever my Victoria! —No more, but straight go to thy Chamber and wait for the happy Issue: — You Sir keep close to me: — Quit her! as chearfully, as I would a Shooe that wrings me. Then how loosely shall I move,
Free and unbounded, taste the sweets of Life!
Love where I please, and know no more the strife
That's bred by that Domestick Plague, call'd Wife. Exeunt.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT. SCENE Victoria's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: NOW I am satisfi'd I must be wretched! Oh Love! Unhappy Women's Curse, and Men's slight Game to pass their idle time at: I find too in my self the Common companion of Infamy, Malice. Has Goodvile's Wife ever wrong'd me? Never. Why then should I conspire to betray her? No, let my Revenge light wholly on that false perjur'd Man; as he has deceiv'd and ruin'd me, I'le play false with him, make my self privy to his whole Design of surprizing Truman and his Wife together: Then like a true Mrs. betray his Counsels to her, That she like a true Wife may spight of his Teeth deceive him quite, And so I have the pleasure of seeing him a seal'd stigmatiz'd fond believing Cuckold: 'Twill at least be some ease to me. Here he comes equip't and prepar'd for the pretended Journey.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Go bid the Coachman hasten, and get all things ready: I am uneasie till I am gone. 'Tis time we were set out.

q.l: The Wolves have prey'd, and look the gentle Day
Before the Wheels of Phoebus all about
Dapples the Drousie East with Spots of Gray.

sp.p: Wife! Adieu dear Wife. Ah my Victoria, up already? so diligent to wish me a happy Journey? Certainly my good Angel is like Thee, and whensoe'r I err must meet me in thy shape. And with such softness smile and direct me.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.l: As those whom Will with the Wisp bewitches
Through Bogs, through Hedges and Ditches.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
No: Thou hast led me out of the crooked froward Road of Matrimony, into the pleasant easie path of Love, where I can never leave
my way, and must be always happy: But where's Malagene?

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Below with Sir Noble. Whilst the Butler was asleep they stole the Key from him: And there they are with the Fat-Red-Fac'd-Fidler that plays upon the Base, sitting Cross-leg'd upon the Floor, stript to their Shirts, and drinking Bawdy-Healths.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: That fulsome Rogue will ruin all our Business. See here what I have discover'd just now in the private Corner of a Window, (a place I suppose appointed for the purpose!) I found this Billet to my sweet Wife.
sp.stage: Reads. If Goodvil goes out of Town this morning, let me know it, that I may wait on you, and tell you the rest of my Heart, for you do not know how much I love you yet, Truman.
sp.p: Now if I am not a Cuckold let any honest Wittall judg, ha, ha, ha. How it pleases me! Blood! Fire! and Daggers!

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: But Sir! what do you resolve on?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: As I told Thee, instantly to pretend a Journey out of Town, and return and surprize 'em; for I am sure they'l not be long asunder when I am out of the way: Oh! this Billet is a very honest Billet, and I know won't lie. But why should I spend my Time in talking of what but vexes me, when pleasures are so near me? Come my Victoria take me to thy arms, a moments Joy with Thee, would sweeten Years of Cares. The Devil—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Good morning to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Good night to you Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: How so Sir?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Why good night or good morrow, 'tis all one; Ceremony is the least thing I take care of: You see I am busie.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I must confess, considering the humble Duty of a Wife, 'tis something rude in me, to interrupt you, but I hope when you know my intentions, you'l pardon me. They were only to take a civil leave of you: I find you are preparing for the Country Sir.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Ay! A little Air will be very seasonable at present Madam, I shall grow rank else, and all the Company I keep will smell me out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Oh what joy will fill each neighbouring Village! to hear our Landlords Honour's coming down. The Bells shall jangle out of Tune all Day; and at night the Curate of the Hamlet comes in the name of the whole Parish to bid his Patron welcome into the Country, and invite himself the next Lords Day to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I am glad to see you so pleasant Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Then the next Morning our Tenants dainty Daughter is sent with a Present of Pippins of the largest Size, cull'd by the good old Drudg her Mother, which she delivers with a Curt'sie, and blushes in expectation of what his VVorship will bestow upon her.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh Madam, let not any thoughts of that Nature disturb you, I shall leave all my wanton Inclinations here, and only please my self when I am there sometimes to contemplate your Ladiships Picture in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Grodv.
sp.p: Then come the Country Squires, and their Dogs, the cleanlier sort of Creatures of the Two: Straight w'are invited to the noble Hunt, and not a Deer in all the Forest's safe.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No Madam: No horned Beast shall suffer for my pleasure: I am lately grown a Philosopher, Madam; and find, we ought not hurt our fellow Creatures.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: What is the reason that you use me thus?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: What is't I would not do to purchase quietness? Your injurious suspicions of me were tolerable, but the wrongs your Jealousie has done Victoria—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I jealous of Victoria! No. Tho' my passion last night made me extravagant, when I discover'd you with that naughty Lady Squeamish which I can easily forgive, if you'l but promise to forget her: For I am confident it was your first Transgression.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Very quaint and pretty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Yet I am too well satisfi'd of Victoria's Vertue, for she's my Friend, and though I should see her in your Arms I could not harbour such a thought. No, Victoria, you must love me, and I'le love you; you shall call me your Love, and I'le call you my Dear, and we'l always go to the Play together, and to the Park together, and every where together; and when Mr. Goodvil's out of Town, we'l lie together.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir the Coach is ready.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: You think Madam, you have a fine easie Fool to play withal, but the gayness of your Face is too thin to hide the rancour of your Heart; and so my Dear jocund witty Devil Wife, I take my leave of you, never more from this minute to look on you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Are you then inexorable? Relentless, cruel Man!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Good easie melting kind-hearted Woman farewel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Ah wretched me.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: My Lady Swoons, Dear Madam Victoria hasten, and bring my Master back again, you can do any thing with him. Ex. Victo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: No no, Lettice! Let him alone, art thou sure he's gone?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: I hope so Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Then so soon as I am return'd to my Chamber, be sure you go your self to Mr. Truman, and tell him if he has nothing else to do he may come hither to Day.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p:
There is no prevailing with him, he cries aloud his House is infected,
and that no man that values his Health will stay in it. My Lady Squeamish too is arriv'd just as he left the Door: I am sure she'l come in, will you see her Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Oh I am sick at the very name of her: Let all the Doors be barr'd against her, and Gunpowder under each Threshold-place, ready to blow her up, if she but offer an entrance. Lettice, lend me your hand a little: I'l to my Chamber instantly: Oh my Head! Ex. with Lettice.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: This management of hers so charms me, that I can almost forget all the mischief she has done me: 'tis true she reproacht me, but 'twas done so handsomely that I had doubly deserv'd it to have taken notice of it.

sp.speaker: L. Squea.
sp.p: Oh Dear Victoria, what will become of me! I am lost and undone for ever: Oh I shall die, I shall die; the Lord of my Heart, the Jewel of my Soul is false to me.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: What ails your Ladiship? Surely she's distracted?

sp.speaker: L. Squea.
sp.p: Oh Goodvil, Goodvil! the false, cruel, remorseless Goodvil! I came just as his Coach was parting from the Door, yet he would not speak to me, would hardly see me, but away he drove, and smiling mockt my sorrows.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Alas! Her Ladiship is passionate, as I live very passionate.

sp.speaker: L. Squea.
sp.p: So Theseus left the Wretched Ariadne on the shoar, so fled the false Aeneas from his Dido.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: What could you expect less of him, Madam? Falshood is his province: Your Ladiship should have made choice of a civil sober discreet Person, but Goodvil you know is a Spark, a very Spark.

sp.speaker: L. Squea.
sp.p: That, that has been my ruine, it was therefore I ador'd him, what Woman would doat on a dull melancholy Ass, because she might be sure of him? No, a Spark is my Life, my Darling, the joy of my Soul, Oh how I doat on a Spark! I could live and die with a Spark. Victoria, I make you a Confident, and you must pardon me for robbing you of Mr. Goodvil: Come come, I know all.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: Your Ladiship knows more then all the World besides.

sp.speaker: L. Squea.
sp.p: And as I was saying, A Spark is the Dearest thing to me in the World; I have had acquaintance I think with all the Sparks. Well; one of 'em that you know was a sweet Person: Oh he danc'd and sung and drest to a Miracle, and then he spoke French as if he had been bred all his life time at Paris, and admir'd every thing that was French: Besides he would look so languishingly, and lisp so prettily when he talkt; and then never wanted discourse: I'l swear he has entertain'd me two hours together with the description of an Equipage.

sp.speaker: Victo.
sp.p: That must needs be very charming.

sp.speaker: L. Squea.
sp.p: But Mr. Goodvil was a Wit too: Oh I never had a Wit before, for to speak the Truth, now I think on't better, all my Lovers have been a little Foolish I'l swear, ha, ha, ha. Sir Noble and Malagene at the Door drunk.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Scour, scour, scour.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Down goes the Main-Mast, down, down, down. They enter. Malagene roar, roar, and ravish, here are punks in beaten Sattin, Sirrah; Termagant, triumphant, first-rate Punks, you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Victor.
sp.p: How came these Ruffians here?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Ruffians! do you know who you talk to Madam? I am a civill, sober, discreet person; and come particularly to embrace thy lovely Body.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Look you Madam, make no noise about this matter. This is a person of quality and a friend of mine, therefore pray be civill.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Has Mr. Goodvile left no Footmen at home to cudgell such Fops? Fogh— how like drunken journy-men Tailors they look?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Journey-men Madam! hold there! none of your Ladyships Journey-men, that's one comfort! woe to the poor Devil that is I say.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Were Mr. Goodvile at home you durst not talk thus, you scandalous fellow.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Goodvile you say—hark you my Dear, were he here in person, I would first of all decently kick him out of doors, then turn up thy Keel and discover here to thy Kinsman what a leaky Vessel thou art?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Why, what is that Goodvile? will he Wrestle? or will he box for 50 l. Look you, this fellow is my Pimp. 'Tis true his Countenance is none of the best: but he's a neat Lad and keeps good Company.

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Hark you Knight! you'll beare me out in this Business Knight? For under the Rose I have apprehension, that this Carcase of mine may suffer else.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: No more of that Rogue! no more. Take notice good people, this Civil Person shall marry my Sister; she is a pretty hopefull Lady— Truly she is not full thirteen — but she has had two Children already, Odd's heart.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Ridiculous Oaff!

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Come, let us talk Baudy.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: I'll call those shall talk with you presently. Ex. Vict.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Wheugh— she's gone.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Beast! Bruit! Barbarian! Sot!

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Oh law! my Aunt! what have I done now? Madam, as I hope to be— Runs against her and almost beats her backward.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh help! I am murdered! oh my Head!

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Nay Lady that was no fault of mine: you shall see I'll keep my distance, and (as I was saying) if I have offended— Reels against a Table and throws down a China Jarr, and severall little China Dishes.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh insufferable! quickly, quickly, a Porter and Basket to carry out this Swine to a Dunghill.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p:
Look you Madam, no harm! no harm! you shall see me behave
my self notably yet—as for example—suppose now—suppose this the Door. Goes to the Door.
Very well; thus then I move.— Steps forwards and leaves his Peruke on one of the Hinges.
Hah, who was that? Rogues! Dogs! Sons of Whores!

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: Such as we are Sir, you shall find us at your service.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.—

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Where there is such odds, a man may with Honour retire and steal off. Exit Malag.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Where is this Rascall? this Coxcomb? this Fop? how dare you come hither Sir, to affront Ladies and Persons of Quality?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Sir, your humble servant: did you see my Perriwig?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir, you are an Ass; and never wore Perriwig in your life: Jerniè what a Bush of Bryars and Thorns is here? The Main of my Lady Squeamish's Shock is a Chedreux to it.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I know who made it. He was an honest fellow and a Barber, and one that lov'd Musick and Poetry.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: How Sir!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: But, Sir, come close to the business: how durst you treat Ladies so rudely as we saw you but now? Answer to that, and tell not us of Musick and Poetry.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Why, he had all Westminster Drollery and Oxford Jests at his Fingers ends. And for the Cittern, if ever Troy Town were a Tune, he master'd it upon that Instrument, when he was our Butler in the Country: an old Maid of my Grandmothers took great delight in him for it.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: But, Sir, this is nothing to our Business.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Business! hang Business! I hate a Man of Business: If you'll drink or Whore, break Windows, or commit murther, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Sir, will you fight?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Fight! with, whom? for what?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: With me.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: With me.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Ay Sir, with all my heart; I love fighting Sir.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: But will you Sir? dare you?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ay Sir, will you fight? do you think you dare fight?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Why, you sweet perfum'd Jessimine-Knaves! you Rogues in Buckram! were there a Dozen of you I'd beat you out of your Artificiall Sweetness into your own naturall Rankness; you Stinkards! shall I draw my Cerberus and cut you off you Gaudy Popinjaies?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: This Fellow's mad, Saunter! stark mad by Jerico: Dear Knight, how long hast thou been in this pickle? this Condition, Knight? hah?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: What Pickle? what Condition, you Worms?

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis so, the poor Devil must to Bedlam: Bedlam, Knight, the Mad-man's Hospitall.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: What will become of you then you Vermin? There's never a Hospitall for Fools yet; Mercy on me if there were! how many handsome Fellows in this Town might be provided for? Fiddles play within.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hey day! Fiddles!

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Madam Goodvile hearing we were here, hath sent for 'em on purpose to regale us.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Goodvile, Lady Squeamish with the Fiddles playing, Saunter falls to sing the Tune with 'em, and Caper Dances to it. Lettice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Let my Servants take care that all the Doors stand open: I'll have entrance deny'd to no one Fool in Town. Mr. Caper and Mr. Saunter here? then we can never want Company. Come, Madam, let us begin the Revells of the day; I long to enjoy the Freedome I am Mistress of. Lettice, try your Vow.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh Madam! this gallant Spirit ravishes me. Dear Mr. Caper, you and Mr. Saunter were born to be happy! Madam Goodvile has resolv'd to Sacrifice this Day to pleasure—what shall we do with our selves?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Do Madam! We'll dance for ever.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh ay Dance.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: And Sing.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: And Sing.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: And Love.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh ay Love! but Madam Goodvile, have you resolved to wear the Willow, and be very Melancholy — ha, ha, ha—Fiddles! where are you? I cannot endure you out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Willow! hang it, give it to Country Girles that sigh for Clowns; and Melancholy is a Disease for Bank-rupt Beauty: I have yet a stock of Youth and Charmes, unfully'd by the hands of Age or Care, And whilst that lasts what Woman would despair?

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: In the mean time I'll scout out for a Doxy of my acquaintance hard by, return in Triumph, and let Victoria go hang and despair.

div.head: Sings.
div.l: To love is a pleasure Divine,
Yet I'll never sigh or be sad;
They are Coxbombs that languish and pine,
So long as Whores are to be had. —To daroll, darolda.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh secure that deform d Monster, that Rebell of mine: fellowes take care of him and keep him up till I talk with him, and make him sensible of his Enormities.

sp.speaker: Sir Nob.
sp.p: Slaves! Avaunt! if my Lady will have it so, I'll walk soberly into the Garden and consider of what is past. To love is a pleasure, &c

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Is Mr. Truman come?

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: He'll be here presently Madam.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: A Letter for your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Good.
sp.p: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: A Porter brought it to the door Madam: but said, he had no orders to stay for an answer. Ex. Page.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: A Womans hand!

div.stage:
Reads.
Mr. Goodvil's Journy out of Town is but a pretence: He is jealous of you and Mr. Truman, you will find him anon return'd in hopes to surprize you together. Though he has trusted me with the secret, and oblig'd me to assist him in it: yet I would endeavour by this discovery to perswade you that I am your reall Servant,
Victoria.
Postcript,
Beware of Malagene, for he's appointed the Spy to betray you. This is generously done, Victoria, and I'l study to deserve it of Thee: Now if I plague not this wife jealous Husband of mine, let all Wives curse me, and Cuckolds laugh at me! Fiddles! lead in! Mr. Caper and Mr. Saunter pray wait on my Lady, and entertain her a little: I'l follow you presently.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Come Mr. Caper, will you walk?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: A Coranto Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Ay ten thousand ten thousand, Mr. Saunter, I would be always near you Two! Oh for a Grove now, and a purling Brook with that delightful charming voice of yours: Come! let us walk and study which way to divert our Selves.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Allons! for Love and Pleasure: By these Hands —

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: By those Eyes—

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh no more! no more, I shall be lost in happiness!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p:
So: this Consort of Fools shall be the Chorus to my Farce: Now all the Malice, Ill-nature, Falshood and Hypocrisie of my Sex inspire me. Lettice! see Camilla be sent for instantly, she shall join with
me in my Revenge, she has Reason; Mr. Valentine I suppose will be here with Mr. Truman.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: And think you Madam, he durst not answer a fair Ladies Challenge without a Second?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: You would pretend I'l warrant you to be very stout. You Hectors in Love are as arrant Cheats as Hectors in fighting, that bluster, rant, and make a noise for the present; but when they come to the Bus'ness, prove errant Dastards, and good for nothing.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But Madam you should find I dare do something, would you but be civil and stand your ground.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: What think you though of a Cut-throat Husband now behind the hangings? what would become of you then?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Whilst I have such Beauty on my side, nothing can hurt me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Then Sir prepare your self, Mr. Goodvil is really jealous and mistrusts all or more then has past between us. His Journey out of Town was but a pretence, but we shall see him instantly in expectation to catch us together.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Fear him not Madam, these Moles that work under ground are as blind as they are busie: Let him run on in his dull Jealousie, whilst we still find new windings out, and lose him in the Maze.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Then if you wish to preserve me yours, join with me to Day in my design, which is, if possible, to make him Mad, work him up to the height of furious suspicion, and at that moment when he thinks his jealousie most just, baffle him out of it: And let the World know how dull a Tool a Husband is, compar'd with that triumphant thing a VVife, and her Guardian Angel Lover.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: But Mr. Goodvil, Madam, has VVit, and so good an opinion of it too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: 'Tis that shall be his ruin: were he a Fool he were not worth the trouble of deceiving.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Dear Jewel of my Soul, proceed then and prosper. But what must be my part?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: To secure Malagene. That ill-natur'd Villain has betray'd us, and is appointed by Goodvil chief Instrument in the Discovery: He has Cowardize enough to sell his Soul to buy off a Beating: He never told truth enough to be believ'd once so long as he lives.
