Get him but in your power, and he shall own more Villanies then ever were in his Thoughts to commit, or the necessity of our affair can invent to put upon him.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: And I'l be sure of him, or may I never taste those lips again, but be condemn'd to cast Mistresses in the side-box at the Play-house, or what is worse, take up with a Semptress, and drudge for Cuffs and Crevats.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Here he comes!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Oh Monsieur Malagene welcome!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Jack Truman your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Whither so fast I beseech you Sir! a word with you, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why! can I do any thing for Thee? Hast thou any Business for me? Prithee what is it?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Sir! You must lie for me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. Is that all?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Nay Sir you must!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Any thing in a civil way or so Jack! but nothing upon Compulsion Lad! Prithee, let me do nothing upon Compulsion, prithee now!

sp.speaker: Trtm.
sp.p: Then Sir to be brief, this is the Business! Goodvil I hear has been informed by you of what part in the Garden last night, how durst you be so Impudent as to pry into my Secrets, where I was concern'd?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why look you Jack, Curiosity you know! and a natural Inclination which I have—

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: To Pimping.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Confound me Jack thou art much in the right: I believe thou art a Witch. I knew as well man—

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: What did you know?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why I knew thee to be an arch Wagg and an honest Fellow! Ah Rogue prithee kiss me! the Rogue's out of humour.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: No Sir! I dare not use you so like a Friend, you must deserve it better first.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Look you Jack, the truth of the Business is, I am bespoke: But the Love I have to see the bus'ness go forward, may perswade me to much.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Then presently resolve entirely to disown and abjure all the Intelligence you gave Goodvil or promise to your self that where ever next I meet you, I'l cut your Throat upon the spot.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But hark you Jack how shall I come off with the business? I shall be kickt and us'd very scurvily: For the truth is, I did tell —

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: What did you tell?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why I told him you Knave. I won't tell! you little cunning Curr, I told him all man!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: All Sir!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ay hang me like a Dogg, all. But Madam you must pardon me, there was not a word of it true.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: And what do you think to do with your self?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Do? why I'l deny it all again man, every word of it, as Impudently as ever I at first affirm'd it: May be he'l kick me, and b • at me, and use me like a Dog man — That's nothing, nothing at all, Man, I do not value it this! Pulls out a Jews Trump and plays.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: And this Sir, you'l stand to.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: If I do not, hang me up for a Sign at a Bawdy-house-door: in the mean time I'l retire and peruse a young Lampoon, which I am lately the happy Father of.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Nay Sir! you are not to stir from me!

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Oh Madam! shift for your self. Madam Victoria sent me to tell you that my Master is return'd, and that he pretends to come as a Masquerader.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: VVell! since it must be so, I'l deny all indeed! what an excellent Fellow might I have been? Some men now with my stock of honesty, and a little more gravity, would have made a Fortune. VVell: I have been a lazy Rogue; and never knew till now that I was fit for Bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Mr. Goodvil in Masquerade say you?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and two VVomen with him, Madam, they are just now alighted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: VVomen with him! nay then he comes triumphantly indeed. Mr. Truman, do you retire with Malagene. I'l stay here and receive this Machiavel in disguise. Now, once more let me invoke all the Arts of affectation, all the Revenge, the counterfeit Passions, pretended Love, pretended Jealousie, pretended Rage, and in sum the very Genius of my Sex to my assistance. Enter Goodvil and others Masqued.
So! here they come: Now this throw for all my future Peace. Who waits there? Enter Servants.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Madam! you'l excuse this freedome.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: You oblige me by using it: Let all the Company know that these Noble Persons of Quality have honoured me with their Presence: Let the Fiddles be ready, and see the Banquet prepar'd; and let Mr. Truman come to me instantly, I cannot live a minute, a moment without him.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Delicate Devil!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Sir! let me beg your patience for a moment, whilst I go and put things in Order fit for your reception. Ex. L. Goodvile.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Footmen! take care that the Engines which I have ordered be ready when I call for 'em. Truman, I see, is a man of punctual assignation; and my VVife is a Person very adroit at these matters; some hot-brain'd, Horn-mad Cuckold now would be for cutting of Throats; but I am resolved to turn a Civil, Sober, discreet Person, and hate blood-shed: No: I'l manage the matter so temperately that I'l catch her in his very Arms, then civilly Discard her, Bagg and Baggage, whilst you my dainty Doxies take possession of her Priviledges, and enter the Territories with Colours flying.

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: And shall I keep my Coach, Mr. Goodvile?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Ay and Six, my lovely Rampant. Nay, thou shalt every morning swoop the Exchange in Triumph to see what gawdy Bawble thou canst first grow fond of: And after Noon at the Theatre exalted in a Box, give Audience to ev'ry trim amorous twiring Fop of the Corner, that comes thither to make a noise, hear no Play, and show himself; thou shalt, my Bona Roba.

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.p: But Mr. Goodvile, what shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh! thou! Thou shalt be my more peculiar Punk, my Housekeeper, my Necessary Sin; manage all th'affairs of my Estate and Family, Ride up and down in my own Coach attended by my own Footmen; Nose my VVife where ere you meet, and if I had any, breed my Children. Oh what a delicious Life will this be!

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.p: Hear you Sir; the Fiddles? Fiddles without.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh the Procession's coming, put on your Visors and observe the Ceremony.

div.stage: Enter Truman, Mrs. Goodvile, Caper, Saunter, L. Squeamish, Camilla, with Fiddles, a Letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Mr. Caper, Mr. Saunter, you are the Life and Soul of all good Company, command me any thing, command my House, that, and all freedome are yours.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Masques, my Life, my Joy, my Top of Happiness! Sir your humble Servant, by your leave, Madam shall you and I toose and tumble together in the drawing room hard by for half an hour or so? Hah? Cuts.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Fa toldara, toldara, &c. Ah Madam what do you wear a Masque for? Have you never a Nose, or but one Eye? Let me see how you are furnished?

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.p: Sir, if I want any thing 'tis to be doubted you cannot supply me.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: So! sure, this must come to something anon!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Ah were but Mr. Goodvile here now, what a happy Day might this be! But he is Melancholy and Forlorn in the Country, summoning in his Tenants and their Rents, that shining Pelf that must support me in my pleasures.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Is he then Madam so kind a Husband?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Oh the most indulgent Creature in the VVorld! what Husband but He, Mr. Truman, would have so seasonably withdrawn and left me Mrs. of such Freedome? To spend my Days in Triumph as I do, to Sacrifice my Self, my Soul, and all my Sense to you, the Lord of all my Joys, my Conqueror and Protector?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Heav'ns Madam you'l provoke him beyond all patience.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Who Mr. Goodvil! which way shall it reach his knowledge? no, we'l be as secret—

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p:
As we are happy. So subtily lay the Scene of all our Joys, that Envy or Malice, nay the very Husband himself and Malagen •
to boot, well hired t • the Business, shall ne'r discover us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Oh discover us! a Husband discover us! were he indeed as jealous as he has reason, I could no more apprehend discovery then a kindness from him.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: This impudence is so rank, that I can hold no longer. Say you so Madam? He unmasks.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Oh a Ghost! a Ghost! save me, save me. Mr. Truman, see see Mr. Goodvil's Spirit? sure some base Villain has murder'd him, and his angry Ghost is come to revenge it on me.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No Madam, fear nothing. I am a very harmless Goblin, though you are a little shockt at the fight of me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Goodvile return'd? Dear Frank!

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Honest Goodvile, thou seest dear Soul we are free here in thy absence.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: I see you are Gentlemen, and shall take an opportunity to return the Favour. Footmen be ready.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: But is it really Mr. Goodvile then? let me receive him to my Armes; welcome ten thousand, thousand, thousand times. Dear Sir, how does my Picture in the Gallery do?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Oh Madam, it lookt so very charmingly, that I had no power to stay longer from the Dear Loving Originall.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: So, now begins the Battle.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Well Madam, and for your Sett of Fools here: to what end and purpose have you decreed them in this new Modell of your Family? I I hope you have not design'd 'em for your own Use?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Why Sir, methinks you should not grudge me a Coxcomb or two to pass away the time withall, since you had taken your Dearer Conversation from me.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: No Madam, I understand your Diet better: a Fool is too squobb and tender a Bit for your fierce Appetite: you are for a Substantiall Dish, a man of Heat and Honour, such as Mr. Truman I know is, and I doubt not will do me reason.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Ay Sir, when ever you'll demand it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Nay Sirs, no quarrelling I beseech you, what would you be at Sir?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: At rest Madam, like an honest Snail shrink up my horns into my Shell, and if possible hold a quiet possession of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I hope I have done nothing that may disturb your quiet Sir.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Nothing Madam, nothing in the least; how is it possible that any thing should disturbe me! a Sot, a Beetle, a Droan of a Husband, a meer Utensil, a Block for you to fashion all your falsehood on, whilst I must still be stupid, bear my office and never be disturb'd, I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: So, now your Heart is opening; and for your ease I'll give it a little vent my self: you are jealous, alas jealous of Truman, are you?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
And I have no reason Madam, though I come and catch you in his Arms, rowling and throwing your Wanton Eyes like Fire-balls at his
Heart; oh what an Indulgent Creature's Mr. Goodvile! so seasonably to withdraw and leave you Mistress of such Freedom: To spend your Days in Triumph as you do, to sacrifice your self, your Soul and Sense to him; the Lord of all your Joyes, your Conqueror and Protector.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: I am glad to find my Plot so well succeed: I knew of your Jealousy last night, knew too your journey out of Town was but a pretence in hope to return and surprize me with Truman. I was inform'd too of your return but now, and your disguise I knew you through it so soon as I saw you, and therefore I acted all that Fondness to Truman before your face. It was all the revenge I had within my power.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Can you deny your being with Truman in the Garden last night? were you not there so openly, that even the broad Eyes of Fools might see?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: What Fool? what Villain have you dares accuse me?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: One, who though he rarely told truth before, will be sure to do it now; Malagene your Kins-man, Malagene, a hopefull Branch of your own stock.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: The Rascall dares not own it.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: But he shall Sir, though you protect him.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: 'Twas basely done to set a Spy upon your Friend, after the trick you had plaid me with Victoria.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Basely done!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Yes, basely Sir.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Death, you lye Sir! why do I trifle thus when I have a Sword by my Side?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay, look you Frank! you had better be patient. Here shall be nothing done, therefore pray put up.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What again quarrelling? Goodvile, this must not be, Truman is my Friend, and if he has done you wrong, I'll engage, shall make you satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Ay, ay, prithee man, take some other time and don't quarrell now and spoil good Company.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Death! you dancing, talking, metled, frisking Rogues stand off! oh I had forgot—Footmen, where are ye?
Here, take away these Butterflies, and do speedy execution upon 'em as I order'd, do it instantly. They seize 'em.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Nay Frank! what's all this for?

sp.speaker: Saunt.
sp.p: Nay Goodvile, prithee, now as I hope to live.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Away with 'em— Ex. with Cap. and Saunter.
Now for Malagene—Oh, here he comes Madam, who will refresh your Memory! Speak Sir, as you tender Life and Limb, whom did you see together in the Garden last night?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ha! —no body!

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Were not Truman and my Wife there to your knowledge privately?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—Child! no.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Did you not tell me that you overheard 'em whispering in the Grotto together?

sp.speaker: Malag.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Hell and Devils! this fellow has been tamper'd withall and instructed to abuse me. This is all Contrivance, a study'd Scene to fool me of my Reason.
Here, take him hence and harness him with the other two, till he confess the Truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: He shall not go, touch him who dares: must People then be forc'd and tortur'd to accuse me falsely? Ah Mr. Goodvile, how have I deserv'd this at your hands? let not my good name be ravish'd from me, if you have resolv'd to break my Heart, kill me now quickly and put me out of pain.— Malag. runs away.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Nay Madam, here is that shall yet convince—see here a Letter from your Lover left for you in a private Corner, hear me read it. And if you have modesty enough left, blush.

div.stage:
Reads.
If Goodvile goes out of Town this morning, let me know of it that I may wait on you and tell you the rest of my Heart. For you do not know how much I love you yet,
Truman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Death and destruction! it was all my own Contrivance, m • dded with your jealousy, I sought all ways to vex you. I counterfeited it with my own Hand, and left it in a place where you might be sure to find it. To convince you farther. see here a Caution sent me just before by one whom you have trusted and loved too much for my quiet: peruse it and when you have done, consider how you have used me and how I have deserv'd it, Oh. Gives Victoria's Letter.
sp.stage: Journy out of Town—is a pretence,—return and surprize—believe by this discovery—Your Servant Victoria.
sp.p: Victoria, has she betray'd me? nay then, I pronounce there is no Trust nor Faith in the Sex. By Heav'n in every condition they are all Jilts, all false from the Bawd to the Babe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: Now Sir, I hope I may withdraw; from this minute never expect I'll see your Face again: no, I'll leave you to be happy at your own choice. Love where you please, and be as free as if I ne'r had had relation to you. I shall take care to trouble you no more, but wish you may be happier then ever yet I made you.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Stay Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: No Sir, I'll be gone, I will not stay a moment longer; Inhuman, Cruel, false Traitor! wer't thou now languishing on thy Knees, prostrate at my Feet, ready to grow mad with thy own guilt, I would not stop nor turn my Face to save thee from Despair.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: M • s. Goodv.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: To let the World see how much a Fool I can be: art thou Innocent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Goodv.
sp.p: By my Love I am, I never wrong'd you; but you have undone me, ruin'd my Fame and Quiet. What Mouth will not be full of my dishonour? Henceforth let all my Sex remember me when they'd upbraid Mankind for baseness: oh that I could dissemble longer with you, that I might to your Torment perswade you still all your Jealousies were just, and I as Infamous as you are cruel. Ex. in a rage.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Get thee in then and talk to me no more, there's something in thy Face will make a Fool of me, and there's a Devil in this Business, which yet I cannot discover. Truman, if thou hast enjoyed her, I beg thee keep it close, and if it be possible let us yet be friends.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: 'Tis not my fault if we be Foes.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: But now to my Fools, bring 'em forth and let us see how their new Equipage becomes 'em. Oh Dear Valentine! how does the fair Camilla?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith Sir, she and I have been dispatching a trifling affair this morning, commonly call'd Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p: Marry'd! nay, then there is some comfort yet, that thou art fallen into the snare—Valentine! look to her, keep her as secret as thou wou'dst a Murder, had'st thou committed one: trust her not with thy dearest Friend, She has Beauty enough to corrupt him.
sp.stage: Enter Caper and Saunter, their Hands ty'd behind 'em, Fools Caps on their Heads. Caper with one Leg ty'd up, and Saunter Gagg'd.
sp.p: See here these Rogues how like themselves they look. Now, you paultry Vermin, you Rats that run squeaking from House to House, up and down the Town; that no man can eat his Bread in quiet for you. Take warning of what you feel, and come not near these Doors again on perill of hanging. Here, discharge them of their punishment, and see 'em forth the Gates.

div.stage: Enter Lady Squeamish, Sir Noble, and Victoria.

sp.speaker: L. Squ.
sp.p: Oh Gallants your humble Servant. Dear Mr. Goodvile be pleas'd to give my Kinsman Sir Noble, Joy: He has done himself the Honour to marry your Cousin Victoria, whom now I must be proud to call my Relation, since she has accepted of the Title of my Lady Clumsey.

sp.speaker: Sir. Nob.
sp.p: Ay Sir, I am Marry'd, and will be drunk again too before Night as simply as I stand here.

sp.speaker: Goodv.
sp.p:
Sir Noble marry'd? to Victoria too? nay then in spight of Misfortunes—
This Day shall be a Day of Jubilee. But first
Good People all that my sad Fortune see,
I beg you to take warning here by me;
Marriage and hanging go by Destinie.
Especially you gay Young marry'd Blades,
Beware and keep your Wives from Balls and Masquerades.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE, Spoken by Mrs. Barrey.
div.l: WELL Sirs, if now my Spouse and I shoud part,
To which kind Critique shall I give my heart?
Stay, let me look, not one in all the place
But has a scurvey froward damming Face.
Have you resolv'd then on the Poets fall?
Go ye're ill-natur'd, ugly Devils all.
The Marry'd Sparks I know this Play will curse
For the Wifes sake, but some of 'em have worse.
Poets themselves their own ill luck have wrought,
You ne're had learnt, had not their quarrels taught.
But as in the disturbance of a State,
Each factious Maggot thinks of growing great:
So when the Poets first had jarring fits,
You all set up for Critiques, and for Wits:
Then straight there came, which cost you Mothers pains,
Songs and Lampoons in Litters from your brains:
Libels like spurious Brats run up and down,
Which their dull Parents were asham'd to own;
But vented 'em in others names, like Whores
That lay their Bastards down at honest Doors.
For shame leave off this higling way of Wit,
Railing abroad, and roaring in the Pit.
Let Poets live in peace, in quiet write,
Else may they all to punish you unite;
Join in one Force, to study to abuse ye,
And teach your Wives and Misses how to use you,
